{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7020994/niagara-gorge-rim-trail", "title": "Niagara Gorge Rim Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.132864,-79.048062", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7020994", "info-text": {"description": "The route starts at Devil's Hole parking area. The wide trail follows the rim of Niagara Gorge through a hardwood tree groves. The route offers continuous views down to the stunningly blue Niagara River, where you can watch tour boats riding up and down the rapids in the river. \r\n\nAt one mile from the trailhead, a route leading to the right descends into the gorge. Continue straight following the gorge rim. The trail passes through Whirlpool State Park, there are great views of the Whirlpool, as well as bathrooms and picnic tables. The Whirlpool forms at a bend in the Niagara River and spins slowly, collecting debris at its center. \r\n\nFrom Whirlpool State Park, the trail continues along the gorge rim, eventually making its way to Niagara Falls State Park. Follow the trail across a bridge and the Niagara River to stunning views of Bridal Veil Falls. Continue along the popular route to Terrapin Point which offers awesome views of Horseshoe Falls. If you have time, there are many tour opportunities in Niagara Falls State Park, as well as amenities such as gift shops, bathrooms, and restaurants.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7048361/devils-hole-trail-well-maintained-dog-friendly", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 5.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [587, 508], "alt-change": [239, 270], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037404/patterson", "title": "Patterson", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.102981,-78.71617", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037404", "info-text": {"description": "Patterson is an old railroad grade.  Take a look at the profile.  Especially after the junction with Ridge Run and Snowsnake, the grade is incredibly constant.  Climbing this trail is fun because you get in the groove and can zone out all the way to the top.\r\n\nThis trail starts at the lower trailhead of the Art Roscoe Trail Network.  \r\n\nFor those starting all the way from the bottom, this trail starts just to the left of the former ski hill and starts climbing right away.  This first section is the steepest part of the trail, and soon you reach the merge with the end of Ridge Run and Snowsnake.\r\n\nHere it begins its long constant grade climb.  On the way up, it has two left turns as it follows the undulations of the ridge it is climbing.  After the second leftward swing, you soon see the start of snowsnake (its upper terminus).  This signals you are near the top and it's time to pick up the pace and leave everything on the trail.  \r\n\nThe trail ends at the summit trailhead.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 3.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2327, 1592], "alt-change": [898, 182], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 13.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037405/snowsnake", "title": "Snowsnake", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.123732,-78.705229", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037405", "info-text": {"description": "Snowsnake is actually a bit wider than the rest of the trail system.  It also has the steepest hills - sometimes you feel like it is going uphill both ways.\r\n\nThe trail starts off of Patterson Run, just a stone's throw downhill from the Summit Trailhead.  Peel off to the right and start downhill, meeting first a sharp right turn.  The trail soon keeps you honest as you climb back up to the elevation you started, and then some.  This finally gives way to a long downhill, including a sharp, steep turn about halfway down.\r\n\nAfter doubling back to the left, the trail climbs almost back to that sharp turn.  Soon, it begins its longest and steepest descent.  Because you've now shed so much elevation, water starts seeping out onto the trail, so the lower portions tend to be wet.\r\n\nSoon, you reach the bottom and cross the creek.  Which means you start climbing!  After a short climb, the trail ends once again at Patterson Run, but a much lower elevation.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 4.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2267, 1665], "alt-change": [408, 873], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},

As such, it is singletrack and much steeper.  It ups the fun factor compared to the rest of the network, which although extremely scenic and enjoyable due to its grade, is otherwise non-technical.\r\n\nThe Bova downhill starts on Ridge Run at the site of the newly rebuilt lean-to cabin.  The singletrack starts just to the north side of the leanto and starts downhill right away.  The grade increases as you bear left and then make a sharp right turn.  Some large boulders here make some interesting alternate lines if you feel you are up to it.  Watch out for the occasional muddy section here.  \r\n\nSoon the trail smoothes out but continues more steeply until it dumps you out at the top of old abandoned Bova ski hill. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7084456/finger-lakes-trail-italy-hill-to-urbana", "title": "Finger Lakes Trail - Italy Hill to Urbana", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.623896,-77.28104", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7084456", "info-text": {"description": "For much of the trail, expect loose, flat, and often slippery, rocky single- or doubletrack. The entire section is marked with orange blazes. During the spring and early summer, the trail can be significantly muddy.\r\n\nStarting from the parking area along Italy Valley Road (42.6239, -77.2815), begin with a 1,000-foot climb up Italy Hill over 3 miles. At mile 4, descend due south on a rocky road that turns into Dunn Road. Turn right (west) on Italy Hill Turnpike, picking up the trail again on the left in less than 0.5 miles. \r\n\nThe trail crosses Emerson Road, Wetmore Road, and Italy Hill Road in quick succession. There may be many blue maple sap lines crossing the trail in this area; just duck under them. When the trail intersects Pulteney Road, turn right and follow the road down the hill about 0.3 miles, re-entering the trail on the right.\r\n\nAt about mile 19, Bud Valley Campground is on the left. This is the site of a major aid station for Twisted Branch 100k every year, so it's very friendly toward hikers. Around mile 20, as you follow blazes east along Faber Road, do not follow orange blazes right where they quickly dead end in a small clearing with a wooden shack. Instead, continue down Faber Road another 0.5 miles until the trail turns right.\r\n\nAt about mile 22, there is one final major climb of about 600 feet. The rest of the trail to the end of the section is a relatively easy cruise.\r\n\nOn this FLT section, there is parking available along Italy Valley Road  (42.6239, -77.2815), Dunn Road (42.6207, -77.2586), the shoulder of Italy Turnpike (42.5993, -77.2629), the shoulder of Italy Hill Road (42.585, -77.2569), the shoulder of Pultney Road (42.5765, -77.2391), Glodes Corners-Browns Corners Road (42.531, -77.2659), the shoulder of Prattsburg-Pultney Road (42.5077, -77.2718), and the shoulder of Elmboise Road (42.4876, -77.2413).", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7030215/patch-road-descent", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 24.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2075, 1010], "alt-change": [3741, 3003], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 32.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7096807/genesee-valley-greenway-genesee-junction-to-mount-morris", "title": "Genesee Valley Greenway: Genesee Junction to Mount Morris", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.098457,-77.68627", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7096807", "info-text": {"description": "The Genesee Valley Greenway is a rails-to-trails following the old Genesee Valley Canal and the Western New York & Pennsylvania Railroad. It is a work-in-progress, currently connecting Rochester, New York, to Black Creek, New York, with plans to extend the trail to Cuba, New York, and possibly Hinsdale, New York.  It is managed by the New York State Park system.\r\n\nThis section begins at Genesee Junction, the site of an old turntable, near the live rail line south of the airport in Rochester, New York. The Greenway crosses over Black Creek via the stone bridge built for the railway and heads south, passing by the Brookdale Preserve to the west. Pass old locks from the Genesee Valley Canal about mile 3.0.\r\n\nAt mile 5.0, the trail passes under I-90; 2 miles later, the trail crosses Oatka Creek in Canawaugus Park. About mile 9.2, pass the Lehigh Valley Trail and an old rail bridge over the Genesee River. The rail line ran over the Western New York and Pennsylvania Railroad at this point, so you'll pass between the stone pillars that once held up the trestle. Continuing southward, the trail passes fields and forests to York Landing about mile 21.2.\r\n\nThe Genesee Valley Greenway crosses the Genesee River just north of Mount Morris at mile 30.9.  Arrive at a parking area in downtown Mount Morris at mile 32.2. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7105655/west-shore-trail", "title": "West Shore Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.06216,-76.17684", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7105655", "info-text": {"description": "A railing prevents you from wandering off the path - the area to either side of the trail is a delicate ecosystem still in the process of recovery and visitors are asked to stay on the paved paths. \r\n\nThere is an overlook stop looking over the west shore of Onondaga Lake, from which (depending on the season) you may see Bald Eagles and Osprey hunting, tree swallows, gold finches, red wing blackbirds, and perhaps even an oriole. \r\n\nContinue walking as the trail turns left and heads to the amphitheater. This is a public park, so you can look around, but unless there is an event (in which case this section of the trail would be closed) the bathrooms will most likely be locked. \r\nContinue around the amphitheater coming to the lake shore again. Keep an eye out for killdeer (birds that pretend to be injured to lure predators away from their nests) and Canada Geese. As you come to the end of the amphitheater area, turning to leave through another set of gates, keep eyed peeled for a mated pair of Bald Eagles who seem to hunt and live at the nine mile creek outlet. \r\nAfter crossing the creek on a bridge, this path runs close to 690 (there's a fence, though, so it's safe) and bends away from the lake shore through some woods. You'll see wild flowers and even some blackberry bushes.\r\nYou can, if you want to, continue on the west shore trail all the way to long branch park at the north west end of Onondaga lake, or you can turn around here and head back to the Orange lot for a nice 3 mile round trip in & out hike.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [429, 357], "alt-change": [140, 136], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7021926/bluff-trail", "title": "Bluff Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.290226,-76.90655", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7021926", "info-text": {"description": "Starting from the public parking lot on East Bay Road (restrooms available) the trail ascends a set of stairs. From the stairs, there is a very steep dirt path that is dotted with trees to help less experienced hikers. It is this section only (and it's very short\u2014just steep) that would be considered \"Intermediate\" in difficulty, but once you reach the top, you are at the top of the bluffs. There are typically 2 parallel paths for most of the trail\u2014one right along the cliff's edge (with signs warning that the edge may be unstable) and one 20 feet farther back in the woods. These paths will merge and diverge very frequently. \r\n\nFrom the initial ascent along the bluffs themselves, the path is very flat. As you come to the end of the bluffs, the path will gradually descend to 8-10 feet above the lake and continue all the way to the park.\r\n\nSince there are other trails in the park, you can make your own hike by combining them. If you are only hiking the Bluff Trail, it is recommended to drop down to the beach in any one of a number of openings and paths along the shore and make the return hike along the rocky shore. It's a flat hike back, but the shifting gravel, stones, and downed trees on the beach require some dexterity to maneuver. But, looking up at the bluff you were on top of a short while ago makes it worth it!", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7023595/looking-out-over-the-water-from-the-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 1.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [404, 259], "alt-change": [164, 177], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 38.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7034701/letchworth-state-park-flt-branch", "title": "Letchworth State Park FLT Branch", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.722055,-77.912223", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7034701", "info-text": {"description": "This is a section of a branch trail to the Finger Lakes Trail (FLT) (Note: this is open to bikes during the summer so be aware of other users on the trail). \r\n\nThe trail starts at the Hogsback Overlook parking lot, which is on your left side of the road to the Mt. Morris Dam.  The trail starts out paralleling the magnificent lower gorge of the Genessee River with some spectacular views.  The trail travels inland often to cross some tributaries, but after a few miles, it follows very close to one of the steepest and deepest part of the lower gorge, with some short side trails to overlooks.  \r\n\nSoon after these spectacular views, there is an intersection in a pine grove that allows you to bail out to the road paralleling the park.  Staying on the trail, you go right down a long descent.  You now enter the central part of the park where the Genessee Valley is a broad valley rather than gorge.  There are many many tributaries to cross along this stretch.  Some are pleasant with a long slog inward to a good crossing spot and then a downhill along the other side.  Others are much less fun and are classic poor trail design creek crossings which plunge straight into the creek bed, and straight up the other side.  \r\n\nSoon, you climb up to another intersection which is yet another bail out to the road.  But keep continue on because the creek crossings start to diminish and you have many long ups and downs along the tributaries.\r\n\nAfter you pass a log lean to slightly off the trail to your right, you come to another bailout to the road.  Usually you are tired by now, so that is often a good idea.  If not, be prepared for a very long downhill followed by a very long uphill in the next section.  \r\n\nNext you come to the section along Dishmill Creek and it soon it dumps you out on the old tow path that followed the canal that used to bypass the gorge.  This section is a road but then it turns into a grassy towpath - flat and straight.  This gets interupted by a technical part (due to a landslide) as it approaches the upper (most spectacular) gorge.  Upon returning to the old tow path, it passes under the RR bridge, and ends with some singletrack just before ending at the road.  \r\n\nTurn around - it's only 22 miles back! The parking area is large enough to accommodate a dozen or so vehicles. Go through the gate that keeps vehicles off of the Haul Road and plunge into the shady forest.\r\n\nThe Haul Road passes a boat launch, then continues through the forest. A few hills exist, but for the most part, it feels like it's downhill more than uphill. As of fall of 2020, the sluices along the trail have been recently repaired for a smoother trail surface.\r\n\nAs the Haul Road approaches the southern end of the lake, views begin to open up to the lake and the mountains on the other side of the valley. Keep an eye out for kayakers and canoeists - the lake is very popular with paddlers.\r\n\nAt the southern end of Canadice Lake, the trail takes a sharp turn to the left (east) and then ascends a steep hill to the parking area along Canadice Lake Road. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7093577/kisil-point-trail", "title": "Kisil Point Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.700141,-77.939092", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7093577", "info-text": {"description": "The Kisil Point Trail has two official trailheads, one on the main park road just south of the Silver Lake Outlet bridge and the other in the Highbanks Camping area. The trail passes an old picnic area and shelter as it makes it way toward Kisil Point. Kisil Point describes the physical feature where the gorge of Silver Lake Outlet meets the gorge of the Genesee River. The trail passes by the Kisil Falls at the start of the trail near the park road.\r\n\nFrom the main trailhead off main park road follow the yellow blazed trail over a footbridge. The trail reaches a muddy, cleared area where it can be tough to follow the trail. The Kisil Point Trail veers right and climbs, while to the left is a cleared path that descends toward Silver Lake Outlet. At the bottom you'll see the Lower Kisil Falls, while the Upper Kisil Falls can be viewed by climbing on the right bank as you ascend back.\r\n\nThe trail climbs and winds until it reaches the second trailhead along the Highbanks Campground Road after 0.5 miles.  The trail now follows an old woods road as you make your way to the old Kisil Point Picnic Area & Shelter at 0.75 miles. Here the trail splits and you can go left or right (right has some views) as the trail creates a loop. At 1.25 miles the trails meet again and the main trail becomes a hiking  trail again as it begins to descend.\r\n\nAt 1.65 miles you reach Kisil Point. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7023899/finger-lakes-trail-segment-16", "title": "Finger Lakes Trail - Segment 16", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.398221,-76.546209", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7023899", "info-text": {"description": "The trailhead for Segment 16 starts from an underpass of Highway 13. It's here that FLT Segment 16 begins and continues to Seneca Lake. \r\n\nOnce in Robert Treman State Park, you'll start to gain elevation for a vast majority of the rest of the hike. You'll eventually come to a fork in the trail where a shelter is located. If you continue on the trail, you'll hike through several briar bushes. However, you can avoid this by taking the service road up to outhouses located on your left. \r\n\nFrom here, you'll want to take a left and hike past the pavilion, and you should see the white markers again where the trail is located. It's from here on out that the trail has a few rolling hills. FLT - Segment 16 eventually connects with the end of the Rim Trail which will lead you to the parking lot.\r\n\nOnce the trail leaves Robert Treman State Park, the climbing will continue steadily for another 7 miles as the trail heads west and then turns south. The high point of the trail is right about where you enter the Connecticut Hill Wildlife Management Area. From here, you'll enjoy a short down followed by another brief uphill. The final 5 miles of the route is a rolling downhill with a couple steep sections before Segment 16 comes to an end at Gulf Road.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 20.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2102, 448], "alt-change": [3250, 2373], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 29.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7016289/ramapo-dunderberg-r-d-trail", "title": "Ramapo Dunderberg (R-D) Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.28065,-73.963885", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7016289", "info-text": {"description": "This trail goes from one side of the park to the other and is a wonderful sampler platter of all the Hudson Valley has to offer a hiker.  This trail runs concurrently with the Appalachian Trail here and there but leaves the AT occasionally to offer more solitude and avoid the crowds at Bear Mountain. \r\n\nEnjoy alpine-like bald summits of glacially-scoured bedrock, views of lakes and streams, bogs and wetlands, and finally, commanding views of the Hudson River from north to south as well as nearby Bear Mountain.  This trail will test your endurance but offers a wide variety of landscape features and views. \r\n\nConvenient access can be had from the Tuxedo train station. From the trailhead, climb up towards the secret hideout of Claudius Smith, a revolutionary, war-era outlaw who made his hideout in the cave just east of the hill that bears his name on the USGS maps. Some refer to the cave itself as Smith Rock, but check it out either way. The detour is worth it!  \r\n\nYou'll need to make a left to stick with this trail, but from there you'll continue on. Ascend Black Ash mountain for a great view of Lake Sebago, and continue north across a road to a unique rocky area scraped by glaciers and littered with boulders.  After a while, you'll rejoin the Appalachian Trail and travel over a long, LONG series of hills and valleys, eventually crossing the Palisades Parkway. \r\n\nYou are now in Bear Mountain State Park, but the next big mountain is Dunderberg Mountain, which offers great views of the park's namesake peak.  Enjoy the fact that you have just traveled clear across the Hudson Highlands!", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7058990/spring-time-in-harriman-state-park", "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 22.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1362, 15], "alt-change": [4526, 4129], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 49.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7022917/major-welch-trail", "title": "Major Welch Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.312458,-73.991535", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7022917", "info-text": {"description": "An ideal first stage of a Bear Mountain loop, this trail is \"spicier\" than the Appalachian Trail approach, as well as more scenic and more challenging.  Stroll past scenic Hessian Lake on a flat grade, then ascend through woodland, breaking out on to a series of rock slabs that will give you an ever-improving view of the Hudson River valley.  \r\n\nTo access this trail, start at the Carousel in the main Bear Mountain parking lot and walk north along the asphalt towards Hessian Lake.  Pass the lake on the left and go to almost the other end of the lake, where you'll find a trail leaving the pavement up to the left. \r\n\nFollow this trail as it gently curves to the left and suddenly begins to ascend more directly. For an alternative start, the trail can also be accessed from the southern end of Hessian Lake as shown on this map. \r\n\nAfter passing through some rough trail and some newly installed steps, you'll emerge at the first of a series of exposed rock faces. Your shoes should just barely allow you to walk up these faces without the use of hands in dry weather, but maintain three points of contact to be safe!  \r\n\nEach ledge offers a better and better view, first of Popolopen Torne across Popolopen Gorge and Route 6, then the town of Fort Montgomery, then the Bear Mountain Bridge, and north to West Point.  \r\n\nFinally, you'll cross Perkins Memorial Drive (watch out for cyclists and motor vehicles!) and reach the summit plateau, where the trail turns right to contour around under the summit through a mythical-looking pine forest strewn with house-sized boulders, eventually ending at the summit parking lot. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025684/ramapo-dunderberg-trail", "title": "Ramapo-Dunderberg Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.281048,-73.962987", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025684", "info-text": {"description": "One of many trails in Bear Mountain State Park that is best suited for combining with other trails to create a loop rather than taken as an out-and-back. You can get to Bear Mountain State Park from NYC using mass transit by taking the Shortline bus which will drop you off at the lodge. Or you can access this trail by parking in the Anthony Wayne parking area at the Harriman State Park end. \r\n\nFrom there, you can take the Cornell Mine Trail to the middle of this trail just east of Bald Mountain. Or park at the Rampo-Dunderberg parking area on the side of 202/9W/Liberty Drive. From the parking area, the trail climbs up Dunderberg Mountain (redundant, I know) and to the east. The trail provides some great views of the Hudson River and later Bear Mountain. \r\n\nHigh above Jones Point, the trail turns west and eventually meets up with the Cornell Mine Trail. Continue along the red blazes up Bald Mountain and back down to the south. The trail then turns west again to pass just south of The Timp before ending in a ravine that separates Harriman State Park from Bear Mountain State Park. Be mindful of unmarked forest roads in this ravine. \r\n\nFrom the ravine, you'll climb up the southern end of Western Mountain. At the top, the trees are relatively sparse so you can enjoy some nice views. The mountain is fairly broad so the top isn't super steep (unlike both ends) but there are a few rock obstacles along the route that make the route much more entertaining. \r\n\nOnce the descent of western mountain is fairly steep, it will take you to a section of the park with numerous forest roads/mixed use trails. Keep an eye for the red blazes, and rattlesnakes as this is where we encountered our first ever in the wild. \r\n\nThe trail ends at the Appalachian Trail, but where it meets the AT is in the middle of the woods. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033885/three-lakes-trail", "title": "Three Lakes Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.454855,-73.833656", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033885", "info-text": {"description": "The Three Lakes Trail has two access points from the road. The south trailhead is on Dennytown Road. The north trailhead is at Route 301 across from Canopus Lake. I chose to hike from the north. After parking at Canopus Lake, cross Route 301 to catch the blue-blazed Three Lakes Trail.\r\n\nThe first mile is relatively flat as it passes through a forest along a fern-lined trail. After this mile, the trail makes a sharp right at a place that appears to show the trail going straight. The trail straight ahead is the Boy Scout Camp Trail marked with green discs. After a little distance, the trail switchbacks across a stream and then begins a steep climb for a short distance.\r\n\nAfter the trail levels out, you'll approach the first lake on the right: Hidden Lake. Soon after that, you'll come to John Allen Pond, which is very scenic and worth spending time at. At the southern end of the pond, you'll reach Sunken Mine Road. Turn right on the road and follow it for about a quarter-mile. Watch for the Three Lakes Trail to resume on the left side of the road. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035497/fahnestock-trail", "title": "Fahnestock Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.456915,-73.839082", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035497", "info-text": {"description": "The Fahnestock Trail is a through trail but often is done in sections as part of different loop hikes. The west trailhead starts to the right of Hubbard Lodge on Campbell Road.  This initial section shares the path with School Mountain Road Trail.  The Fahnestock Trail is marked with blue discs.  When you reach a stream crossing, the Fahnestock Trail splits off from the School Mountain Road Trail to the right and travels back in the direction you just traveled on the other side of a creek.  When the trail moves away from the creek, the terrain becomes very steep until you reach the top of Round Hill and a few nice viewpoints.  \r\n\nThe trail descends a ridge and after about 3.5 miles you reach a trail junction with the Perkins Trail. The Perkins Trail is marked with yellow discs and shares the same path with the Fahnestock Trail for about .5 miles.  At that point the trails separate and the Fahnestock Trail travels along Clove Creek Pond.  After passing the pond, the trail takes a turn right and you'll pass the Clove Creek Trail on the left.  Continue straight until you reach the Charcoal Burners Trail marked with red discs. The two trail again share the same path until you pass Beaver Pond.  Fahnestock breaks off to the left and follow until the trail ends on the Appalachian Trail.\r\n\nIf taking this trail east to west, you have to park on Route 301 south of Canopus Lake and follow the Appalachian Trail to a steep staircase. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036334/roaring-brook-trail", "title": "Roaring Brook Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.459137,-73.829308", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036334", "info-text": {"description": "The Roaring Brook Trail (marked with white discs) can be accessed from the east side of Pelton Pond or from the Clarence Fahnestock Park Campgrounds. \r\n\nThe trail starts as a well-defined forest road which eventually becomes an overgrown, wide singletrack trail. The Roaring Brook Trail has a gradual descent. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7027369/triangle-trail", "title": "Triangle Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.196394,-74.180002", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7027369", "info-text": {"description": "To get to this trail from the Metro North Tuxedo Stop, follow the East Village Road east under the over pass for I-87. Then turn left onto Grove Drive. Look for Ramapo Dunderberg (R-D) Trailhead. Take the Tuxedo - Mt. Ivy trail north for a very short distance. The yellow-blazed Triangle Trail will then appear. \r\n\nTriangle Trail heads north along the bottom of the valley at the bottom of the Black Ash Mountain. When you are at the northern end of the mountain, the trail will turn southeast to join the White Bar trail. You'll hike along the White Bar for about a third of a mile and then turn northeast on its own. \r\n\nYou'll cross the Ramapo Dunderberg (R-D) Trail trail again at just under three miles - this is also the trail's high point. The trail then heads south to cross the Victory Trail at Lake Skenonto. This is a nice spot for a break! The trail then heads east to Lake Sebago, offering more views. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7026324/notch-trail", "title": "Notch Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.469423,-73.975653", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7026324", "info-text": {"description": "The trailhead for the Notch Trail is at the northern end of Hudson Highlands State Park on Route 9D. There is a small parking lot at this trailhead with space for about 5-6 cars. The Notch Trail is designated with blue blazes and is well maintained with plenty of markers to guide you. There are many unmarked fire roads in this area and it is very easy to lose your way, so be sure to look for the blue marking as you hike to make sure you stay on the correct trail. The first part of the Notch Trail follows these fire roads until it joins the Wilkinson Memorial Trail which point the trail transitions to singletrack.\r\n\nThe portion of the Notch Trail is steep but manageable.  After about 1.5 miles, you reach the first stream crossing at Gordons Brook. After crossing the brook, continue on the Notch Trail for another .5 miles until your second stream crossing of Squirrel Hollow Brook. Here, the Notch Trail joins the Wilkinson Memorial Trail after crossing the brook. Stay on the Notch Trail for another mile until you reach the white-blazed Breakneck Ridge Trail. \r\n\nTurn right here. At this point, the Notch Trail runs concurrent with the Breakneck Ridge Trail for about 1.5 mile until it breaks off to the left and descends the ridge. After about one mile, you'll exit onto a fire road that is usually very wet. Turn right to stay on the Notch Trail.  On the left, there are some intriguing stone ruins which make a good place to take a break. Just after these ruins, turn left and start another steep uphill along a creek. The trail ends at a junction with the Washburn Trail and Nelsonville Trail.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7031015/the-crossing-at-squirrel-hollow-brook-is-usually-straightforward", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 5.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1179, 219], "alt-change": [1519, 602], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 33.0}},

Turn right and ascend to the quarry. The Undercliff Trail ascends the side of Taurus Mountain and is steep at times. There is a tricky section at the only viewpoint on the Undercliff Trail. \r\n\nThere are several social paths that lead away from the trail. Many people get confused here. After the trail climbs up to this viewpoint, it makes an abrupt turn back and descends again before climbing back up the side of the mountain. It is not well-marked here so take your time to find the right way.\r\n\nThe northwestern section of the Undercliff Trail, once you cross over the Washburn Trail, is seldom visited as most people either hike the Washburn Trail or Breakneck Ridge Trail. This section connects the Washburn Trail and the Brook Trail. The trail has some of the best viewpoints of West Point and Storm King Mountain across the Hudson River. This trail sees little traffic and is very enjoyable. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025747/bare-rock-trail", "title": "Bare Rock Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.200875,-74.266033", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025747", "info-text": {"description": "A trail running from the Sterling Forest parking area up a ridge where it meets the Sterling Ridge Trail. Continue on the trail down a small ravine with a creek and the West Valley Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7005676/rock-trail", "title": "Rock Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.23964,-73.587563", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7005676", "info-text": {"description": "The Rock Trail was developed to connect the six rock features of the park: Dancing Rock Loop Connector, Indian Rock Shelter, Raven Rocks, Castle Rock, Bear Rock Petroglyph, and Spy Rock. \r\n\nSections are very steep with one section being an actual rough-hewn rock staircase that climbs 150 vertical feet. \r\n\nThe rock features are as follows:\r\n-Raven Rocks and Spy Rock are the two overlooks on the southeast section of the trail.\r\n-Bear Rock petroglyph (google it!) is a verified carving at least 5,000 years old created by Native Americans. The carving is on a boulder and is in the shape of a bear and several other local animals. \r\n-Indian Rock Shelter is a former native American campsite. \r\n-Castle Rock is a rock formation which somewhat resembles a castle.  \r\n-Dancing Rock is a large flat rock that was the site of late night dancing by local families after a harvest moon in the late 1800's and early 1900's.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Cave \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7009364/raven-rocks-overlook-panorama", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 5}, "stats": {"dist": 5.3, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [814, 446], "alt-change": [952, 957], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 43.0}},

Because there is a road to the summit of Whiteface Mountain, this trail gets little traffic. It has two very steep sections and a very flat section in between that tends to be full of water or at least very muddy even when it is not raining.\r\n\nAfter about two miles, the trail levels out. Soon after, you'll pass a trail junction (marked by a massive cairn and orange post) with the trail to the summit of Esther Mountain (Esther Mountain Trail). About a quarter mile past this, you'll pass the remnants of an old section of a ski resort lift. This is at almost exactly 4,000 feet in elevation and the trail becomes steep again after this point. \r\n\nJust before the summit ridge, the trail parallels Route 431 but does not cross the road. The summit ridge is long and exposed. Be prepared for the possibility of very high winds.\r\n\nUnfortunately, you'll not be alone on the summit because of the road to the top. You'll have the satisfaction of climbing to the top of a 46'er while all the others drove up. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7090815/5-mile-trail", "title": "5 Mile Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.057506,-73.802512", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7090815", "info-text": {"description": "This trail features both rugged singletrack, gravel road and some paved road. Begin at the concourse near the Hall of Springs and head south past the Lincoln Baths and into the woods. The trail descends moderately steeply to the Geyser Loop road, crosses the Geyser brook and turns sharply right following the brook on a singletrack path past the natural, gas geyser to a small waterfall beneath the bridge to the Saratoga Performing Arts Center. Here you'll pass a natural tufa outcrop, one of the few on the east coast. \r\n\nFrom the waterfall, ascend the stairs to the top of the cliff and proceed to follow the path under the bridge and past the Orenda Spring. The park has many fresh water and naturally carbonated springs that were considered healthful in the past. Feel free to sample the water, but most of the people who like the water are locals.\r\n\nJust past the spring the trail re-enters the woods and emerges near a picnic pavilion where it crosses the Geyser Loop Road and once again joins a singletrack which rolls through beautiful hardwood forest until it encounters a gravel road which leads to the Peerless Pool complex, which the trail skirts around in the woods.\r\n\nThe trail ascends a slight grade and crosses the East-West Road at the South Route 50 entrance. Crossing the road it follows a power line blaze for a short distance before it becomes a singletrack and passes a small pond with an observation blind for bird watching. You can typically find Canadian Geese, ducks, Great Blue Herons, and many other birds here.\r\n\nThe trail turns sharply left and descends to the power line blaze again where it turns left once more. A short distance and the trail goes back into the woods where it rolls along for a distance until it crosses the East-West Road. Another short distance and you emerge near the parking lot for the Peerless Pool. It then traverses in front of the parking lot on a lawn that doubles as a Frisbee Golf course.\r\n\nThe course arcs around the pool complex and picks up the trail again as it descends steeply to the Geyser Creek where it turns right and follows to a bridge on the East-West Road. Cross the creek here and ascend back into the woods where it rolls easily along eventually running along the crest of the beautiful Ferndell Gorge. The trail encounters the North-South Road where the trail up Ferndell intersects but immediately dodges left back into the woods. In a short distance the main concourse is once again encountered.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Fishing \u00b7 Geological Significance \u00b7 Historical Significance \u00b7 Spring \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 5.0, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [386, 226], "alt-change": [780, 778], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},

It is also one of the easiest because of it's easy access and relatively flat, well-maintained trail. This section spans the Palisades, a long cliff overlooking the Hudson River and New York City. There are many viewpoint and stone ruins along the way from a time when the area was a popular weekend tourist location for people from NYC.  \r\n\nThis section is known as section one and is about 14 miles long spanning from the George Washington Bridge in Fort Lee, NJ and traveling north along the Palisades to the border with New York State. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7030642/the-high-line", "title": "The High Line", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=40.756299,-74.003662", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7030642", "info-text": {"description": "The High Line is one of New York City's newest and most imaginative public parks. Open as a park since 2009, it reimagines an old section of railroad track that carried freight into Manhattan industrial neighborhoods from the 1930s through the 1980s. Though it can be quite crowded on weekends and on gorgeous days, the park still provides a wonderfully green escape from the city streets. \r\n\nThe High Line runs from Gansevoort Street on the south end to 34th Street on the north end, from Chelsea to Hudson Yards, weaving back and forth between 10th and 12th Avenues. Along the way, you'll pass by art installations, playgrounds, overlooks, seating areas, cafes, and underpasses. Multiple entrances along the way provide ample opportunities to sneak down to street level and explore the city.\r\n\nAn events calendar, volunteering information, background on all the art, the High Line's history, and much more can be found at the Friends of the High Line page.", "features": "Views", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7031604/a-veritable-forest-has-grown-between-the-tracks-on-the-high-line", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 1.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [16, 10], "alt-change": [6, 12], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 1.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7102124/sunken-forest-trail", "title": "Sunken Forest Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=40.656917,-73.104736", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7102124", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is a boardwalk and it is the main trail at Sailors Haven in Fire Island National Seashore. It is unblazed but is very easy to follow. The name of this trail stems from the unique maritime holly forest through which it leads that seems to be sunken into the sand dunes. In addition to the trail, there are many areas with benches and for observation.\r\n\nThe trail begins at the visitor center and marina. For about the first half of a mile, it heads pretty straight in an eastward direction. It then reaches what is referred to as the \"Heart of the Forest.\" This area has plenty of seating and is the beginning of this trail's loop. It continues eastward until it passes two spurs to overlooks along the Great South Bay. The trail then turns southward over the island's dunes.  \r\n\nNext, the trail passes over the sand Burma Road and turns westward as it double tracks with the Swale Trail. Once the trail passes an access trail to the beach, it turns northward.  Here, it follows the sometimes winding boardwalk back to the heart of the forest and, finally, follows the walk back to the visitor center.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7079527/the-gateway-to-the-sunken-forest", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.5, "dist-type": "Lollipop", "alt-range": [0, -2], "alt-change": [4, 4], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 0.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032866/wallkill-valley-rail-trail", "title": "Wallkill Valley Rail Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.646694,-74.164479", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032866", "info-text": {"description": "Limited road-side parking at Denniston Road, but ample parking two miles north in Gardiner. The Wallkill Valley Rail Trail has mile markers every half mile from Denniston Road. \r\n\nAlong the way, the trail passes near Skydive the Ranch then Gardiner Center, Majestic Park, orchards and forests. Also nearby are organic farms and farmer's markets. Stop at Plattekill Creek for a great view of the Gunks at mile 6.5. At mile 8 is Sojourner Truth Park with kayak launch. The WVRT then passes Water Street Market in New Paltz with restaurants and shops and Main Street businesses and at mile 9 is the Huguenot Historic District, oldest continuously inhabited street in the US. Woods and farms dot way until the spectacular Rosendale Trestle at mile 15.5. Once the highest bridge in the US, Rosendale was the source of the cement that would build the Brooklyn Bridge and the world's first skyscrapers. Further north are lakes and the home turf of the sociological and infamous \"Jukes\" clan. There, numerous old cement mines emitting chilly breezes (and bats at night) along the way. \r\n\nThe trail's northern end currently terminates at a large parking area. Take a road route to Kingston's historic Stockade District with its restaurants and small shops. Downhills and uphills mainly consist of going into and out of ravines. \r\n\nA big feature of this trail is the half dozen or so downhills that are basically stairs created by timbers and fill. There are the usual assortment of roots, so be sure to watch your footing.\r\n\nBe aware that this trail is shared with mountain bikers and other trail users. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7100396/catskill-scenic-trail", "title": "Catskill Scenic Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.302734,-74.554141", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7100396", "info-text": {"description": "Utilized for many decades as a vital cog in the Catskill Region's economy, the railroad line in this area eventually fell victim to the other modes of transportation that were deemed more economical.\r\n\nFortunately, the former rail line was viewed as having a new type of useful life as a \"Rails to Trails\" project. Through the generous financial support of several area organizations, work was begun in the 1990s to turn the path of the former Ulster & Delaware Railroad into a recreational trail that can be enjoyed year-round for horseback riding, bicycling, jogging, walking, cross-country skiing and snowshoeing. The CST is also popular with \"horse and carriage\" enthusiasts who enjoy the wide path and smooth grade..\r\n\nWith its wide path, gentle grade and durable surface, the Catskill Scenic Trail has become an ideal recreational destination as it traces a leisurely path through stunning Catskill Mountain terrain. The CST is enjoyed year-round by thousands of folks in a variety of pursuits.\r\n\nAs the was thriving as a tourism attraction, plans were pondered as how to best utilize the vacant rail line from Roxbury, NY to Bloomville, NY. The nearly flat grade of this section of former rail bed made this area ideal the type of \"rails to trails\" project that was growing in popularity throughout the country. Funding was put in place by the Catskill Revitalization Committee and plans were drawn up to remove the old rails and ties. Brush was cut, the path suitably widened and a surface of compact cinders and dirt was put in place. The Catskill Scenic Trail was ready to begin its new life an perfect place for family-oriented recreation.\r\n\nThe hard-packed base is ideal for biking, hiking, cross-country skiing and horseback riding. The Catskill Scenic Trail has also become a popular destination for \"horse and carriage\" enthusiasts who appreciate the wide path and gentle grade.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Fishing \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 2.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 26.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1846, 1447], "alt-change": [899, 922], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 6.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7100410/dh-canal-trail-mamakating", "title": "D&H Canal Trail: Mamakating", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.631891,-74.452559", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7100410", "info-text": {"description": "The Delaware & Hudson Canal Linear Park is 45 acres with a trail situated along the historic D&H Canal. Remains of the original locks, dry dock and waste weirs are visible from the towpath trail. Interpretive signs are located in the park to assist the visitor identify the various canal structures. The trail is ideal for hiking, biking, cross-country skiing, snowshoeing, nature watching and fishing. Use of motorized vehicles and horseback riding are prohibited on the trail.\r\n\nThe trail occupies the right-of-way of the former New York, Ontario, and Western Railway Main Line through eastern Sullivan County. Note that the unpaved surface of the trail surface can be rough in some sections. Picnic tables and grills along with porta-johns are available at both accesses. The Bova Road access has a group picnic pavilion (fee).\r\n\nOne segment of the trail, between Firehouse Road at US 209 north to Herlings Road in Phillipsport, is privately owned. You can bridge that portion at the Bova Road access by taking Ministers Flats Road to Phillipsport Road to Herling Road.\r\n\n\nParking and Trail Access\r\nTwo accesses are open at this time, both located off Route 209. Hornbeck's basin access is located 1/2 mile north of Wurtsboro; the Bova Road access is located 4.5 miles north of Wurtsboro between the Hamlets of Summitville and Phillipsport.\r\n\nThe Park itself is open year-round from 8 a.m.-dusk. The Interpretive Center is open from Memorial Day Weekend through Columbus Day Weekend on the following days:\r\n\nFriday and Saturdays: 10 a.m. \u2013 5 p.m.\r\n\nSundays: 12 p.m. \u2013 5 p.m.\r\n\nAdmission:  Free\r\n\nDue to the linear nature of this park users are asked to respect the rights of adjacent landowners.\r\n\nThe canal was 108 miles long (Honesdale, PA to Kingston, NY) and contained 108 locks, 22 aqueducts, 136 bridges, 22 reservoirs, 16 dams and 14 feeders.", "features": "Fall Colors", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 6.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [536, 519], "alt-change": [62, 65], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037904/black-trail", "title": "Black Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.707719,-77.416937", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037904", "info-text": {"description": "The Black Trail is the newest addition at Ontario County Park. It occupies a lower bench on the east side of the park and adds approximately four miles and 600 feet of elevation change to the network.  \r\n\nThe Black Trail has a few options for looping, the most interesting of which is a figure-8, hiking the north half clockwise and the southern loop counter-clockwise. Doing so earns you a full mile and 370 vertical feet of descent, a rarity in the Genesee Valley region. The climb out has some steep moments but is well-built and manageable for most.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2124, 1671], "alt-change": [597, 494], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 20.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037905/brown-trail", "title": "Brown Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.706749,-77.411736", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037905", "info-text": {"description": "The Brown Trail forms a long spindly loop, heading from the top of Ontario County Park to the bottom and back. Most of Brown is narrow, bench cut into a steep side-slope. Expect short descents, little punchy climbs, and plenty of switchbacks. \r\n\nNote that on some maps, this trail is marked as the Tan Trail. The trail is marked with brown blazes. \r\n\nThe northern part of this trail is arguably best done counter-clockwise, climbing along the Park Drive and descending the western side parallel to the Black Trail. This fun descent places you at the trail's lowest point. Cross the boardwalk and continue onto some steep Finger Lakes-style switchbacks. Eventually, you'll reach the southernmost point in the trail network. Keep bearing left at each intersection to take the Brown Trail back if desired.\r\n\nThe Brown Trail provides access to the Black Trail in two places - in the northwest, near one of its highest points, and in the middle, at Brown's lowest point, just beyond a boardwalk. It also intersects the Yellow Trail in the south end of the park, providing some excellent options for loops between the two. \r\n\nThe southern part of the Brown Trail can feel confusing, as the trail parallels itself and the western side of the Yellow Trail. The steep side slope makes the three lines seem much further apart than they appear on a map. When in doubt, downhill on your left side usually means you're headed north towards the park, and downhill on your right means you're headed south and away from the car.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7038210/jump-off-platform-on-the-finger-lakes-trail-in-ontario-county-park", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 2.8, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [2204, 2021], "alt-change": [364, 362], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},

At the southern end of Cross Mountain, open rock ledges offer a fantastic view of the surrounding area, including numerous Catskill peaks. From the trailhead, follow the yellow-blazed trail as it makes its way up strenuous grades. So steep in fact, that two wooden ladders have been created to help with certain sections. After passing the ladders, the trail turns left on a narrow tread, ascending gradually for over a mile until it drops down a rocky descent to a stream. Get ready to climb again before turning on an old carriage road for about 2 miles.\r\n\nEventually, you'll reach a junction with the Giant Ledge-Panther Mountain-Fox Hollow Trail (Blue). If you intend to complete this segment of the Phoenicia East Branch Trail (Yellow) -\u00a0East, continue straight through this juncture to reach the trail's end on Route 47. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032632/oswego-county-trail", "title": "Oswego County Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.31163,-76.377353", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032632", "info-text": {"description": "The Oswego County Trail is a point-to-point route that follows an abandoned right-of-way of the old New York Ontario & Western Railroad between Cleveland and Fulton. The trail is actually in two segments, divided by Interstate 81 in the village of Central Square.\r\n\nThe trail is a straightforward route without much meandering. It passes through scenic countryside and hardwood forests. Occasionally, the trail surface is rough and rutted.\r\n\nMany of the railroad bridges have been preserved and resurfaced as crossings.\r\n\nThis is a multi-use route open to hikers, mountain bikers, ATVs, and snowmobiles.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 27.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [433, 371], "alt-change": [344, 302], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036103/main-sprague-brook-loop", "title": "Main Sprague Brook Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.587927,-78.622359", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036103", "info-text": {"description": "This is the main singletrack loop, the first loop WNYMBA constructed after its proposal to start building trails was accepted in 2004.  \r\n\nMany parts of Sprague Brook Park are flat and thus have limited drainage, and thus would make for muddy trails.   So this trail was designed to be routed almost entirely adjacent to the course of Sprague Brook as it travels through its namesake park.  This allows for adequate drainage by using the slope down towards the brook, or running near the edge of the ravines, which take advantage of the lowered water table, which is lowered by the many seeps along the ravines.  \r\n\nThis routing has its advantages and disadvantages.  In addition to allowing for a drier trail, it also provides some spectacular views into the ravines.  However, the edges tend to have a lot of spruce growth which, following compaction of the trail from use, sports many relentless rooty sections which can be easy to trip on.  Overall, though, the trail has become extremely popular in the first 8 years since it was built.\r\n\nThe trail starts from the XC ski loop, about a third of the way around.  A kiosk marks the start, and the hiker is immediately greeted with some very rooty sections for about the first half mile.  After that, it settles down a bit into a smoother singletrack as it crosses a tributary, only to reenter the spruce as it heads back to the main ravine.  \r\n\nIt follows the ravine except for two more tributaries which it follows up and crosses near the park boundary.  The second of these sports a new massive bench cut on a steep sidehill that replaces a formerly used two-track that was always wet and steep.\r\n\nAfter one more tributary crossing (the aptly named \"ditch\"), the trail makes its descent to cross Sprague Brook just before the park boundary.  This is a get-your-feet-wet crossing.\r\n\nAfter a steep climb up to the opposite side of the ravine, the trail continues back, the time following the brook downstream.  Once again, some spruce sections rear their ugly roots.  This side also has lots more water coming in from the west, so even with the routing near the ravine edge, WNYMBA has had to haul in a lot of stone to keep the trail in good shape.\r\n\nEventually, the trail nears the upper campground.  After another kiosk located where the trail briefly touches the campground connector, the trail starts a long rooty downhill until its end at the snowmobile climb.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7058615/on-the-main-loop", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 4.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1542, 1366], "alt-change": [236, 330], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 14.0}},

This trail is actually several segments linked together to make an alternate way to climb up to the top of the ravine to do the main loop.\r\n\nThe trail starts off the Snowmobile Climb, soon after that trail's start.  Look for the \"Mordue Way\" on the the left, named after long time WNYMBA member Larry Mordue who lost his battle with cancer.  This beautiful bench cut leads to a snowmobile trail section, whereupon you zig left and then zag immediately to the right to access some singletrack through a spruce grove, roots and all. This short section dumps you out on another old section of snowmobile trail that climbs up to your left.  \r\n\nJust as the grade starts to ease, take the singletrack on your right, for a nice section through some pines and around some small ponds.  This section of singletrack eventually ends on another old snowmobile trail at the edge of a field.  Take that 2-track down the hill, over the creek and back up the other side, where you'll see the singletrack start once again on your right. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7079511/skunk-ridge-to-creekside", "title": "Skunk Ridge to Creekside", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.585387,-78.641664", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7079511", "info-text": {"description": "These two trail segments are always done together.\r\n\nThe trail starts at the foot of the sledding hill, just west of the function building. It starts as a sidehill bench cut trail heading off to the left, climbing until it gains the ridge \"skunk ridge\".  Here the trail makes a sharp right and continues along the spine of the ridge.\r\n\nYou'll make a brief appearance at the top of the sledding hill before ducking back into the woods on your way to the top of the fields that slope down to the west and route 240, with Kissing Bridge ski area in the distance.  The trail then starts a very smooth descent along the edge of the fields. Eventually, a sharp right brings you down to an old service road paralleling the creek. Go left on the service road for a couple of hundred yards and then head right for the creek crossing. Yes, your feet will get wet.\r\n\nOne you cross the creek, you are on Creekside. As the name implies, this trail follows the creek back upstream. The creek bank here is all outwash sand and gravel, meaning two things. First, it's a trail that is always dry no matter what, with a naturally gravelly tread. Second, the poorly cohesive soil means that the creek valley is constantly widening, so the trail needs to be periodically moved inward from time to time.\r\n\nThis is a very nice section with lots of twists and turns despite paralleling the creek. \r\n\nThe trail ends at the park road, opposite the start of the snowmobile climb.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1396, 1264], "alt-change": [57, 132], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7079517/accidental-trail", "title": "Accidental Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.595744,-78.623725", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7079517", "info-text": {"description": "This trail adds another 0.4 miles to the Main Sprague Brook Loop.  It gets its name from when WNYMBA was building the main loop. Taking a shortcut through the woods, building began along an old stretch of trail to be repurposed into the main loop.  Except it was the wrong old stretch of trail.  Oops.  \r\n\nThe area was quite wet and was quickly abandoned as the builders moved onto the the correct old stretch. However, enough was \"built\" that it started getting some use, which was a shame because it was extremely wet from no drainage. Eventually, rather than fight it, the trail was armored with lots of rock and corduroy and added to the system. Always good to have more mileage.\r\n\nThe loop begins and ends at the Main Sprague Brook Loop, on opposite sides of a small creek crossing.  If you're doing the main loop clockwise, you'll see if veer off to the left at about 1.5 miles in.  It makes a hard right at a heavily armored turn and then meanders to the above-mentioned \"old stretch of trail\". \r\n\nThe Accidental Trail itself veers right along the \"old stretch\", eventually leading to some wet creek crossings. Soon it loops back towards the main loop. As it parallels the swamp that feeds the creek separating the start and end of the trail, long sections of corduroy keep the tread dry until the swamp turns into a creek and the ground is dry once again.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [1539, 1528], "alt-change": [11, 9], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 3.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7079518/snowmobile-climb", "title": "Snowmobile Climb", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.589977,-78.641646", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7079518", "info-text": {"description": "This is one of the original trails in the park, constructed for snowmobile use in winter.\r\n\nThe trail starts on the park road, on the right just after it crosses Sprague Brook (the brook itself). Because it starts off with a steep fall line section, you'll see gravel washed down right to the road.\r\n\nYou'll see the Mordue Way section of the new trail going off to your left; that's always an option, but not what we are describing today. Instead, you continue a steep climb, only to cross a knoll and drop down to a very wet section. Maybe someday we will get the park to put some gravel in here.\r\n\nThe wet soon ends and the trail crosses a bridge and starts climbing again. You'll pass a kiosk at the start of the main singletrack loop, but breeze on past this and continue climbing.\r\n\nThe trail gets steeper and steeper as it nears the top. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032830/ski-bowl-connector", "title": "Ski Bowl Connector", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.694673,-73.991364", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032830", "info-text": {"description": "This is the Ski Bowl Connector to the Raymond Brook Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7007146/yellow-trail", "title": "Yellow Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.188458,-73.701029", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7007146", "info-text": {"description": "The Yellow Trail is very hilly starting from the parking lot. It goes up the first hill to the hawk watch overlook, then it heads down and up and down and up several times. The trail crosses seasonal streams and gullies throughout these undulations, so prepare for your feet to get wet. The final downhill takes you into the lowest point in the park where you can stay on the Yellow Trail (east side) or take the Orange Trail (west side) of the creek that runs north into Howland's Lake. It connects with several white trails along the way that tie it back to the blue and red trails. \r\n\nThe end of the Yellow Trail joins up with the end of the red trail to loop back to the start (via the red trail). There is also a BRLA Connector Trail that leads out onto Sarles Rd but it is pretty sketchy at points (overgrown) with a few trees down that haven't been cleared from heavy storms. The more adventurous can even head up to the Meyer Preserve via the paved Oregon Road.\r\n\nThe trail can also be done in the opposite direction, starting from Sarles Street, where there is a 2\u20133 car parking area designated for the trailhead and Marsh Sanctuary. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7079806/teatown-kitchawan-trail-tkt", "title": "Teatown-Kitchawan Trail (TKT)", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.22048,-73.786557", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7079806", "info-text": {"description": "We started at the Kitchawan Preserve end of the trail. The trail immediately starts down a tree covered path with a few rocks, roots and some mud. After crossing over a stream via bridge, you climb up a surprisingly steep trail to a series of interconnected meadows. After re-entering the woods, following the purple blazes and TKT placards you turn left through a gap in a stone wall and then descend into a ravine. At the bottom of the ravine, take a moment to get a picture or 3 and then cross the stream using the rocks. On the other side of the stream climb the embankment and stay to the right. You'll climb steadily until you come to Arcady Rd.  \r\n\nCrossing Arcady look left for the purple blazes and the TKT placards. After re-entering the woods and climbing a short set of stone steps you'll come to a wide grassy trail, make sure to turn right. For the next 1.5-2 miles you'll not see any TKT placards only far apart purple blazes. Follow the grass trail up a fairly constant incline until it becomes a narrow path again. You'll know that you are on the right path (besides the purple blazes), once you start seeing NYC DEP signs. Eventually you'll break out into old and unused farm fields. Following the trail you'll eventually come to Aqueduct Street and the road portion of the trail.\r\n\nTurning right onto Aqueduct Street you'll slowly descend towards the Croton Reservoir. At the bottom of Aqueduct St you turn left onto Croton Dam Rd which is gravelly and very poorly maintained. On this road you'll have views of the reservoir and the superstructures of the two bridges that cross the reservoir. Keep an eye out to the left for TK placards are purple blazes for the spot you'll be heading off road again.\r\n\nOnce you find the trail, turn left, take a deep breath and gird yourself for a steep ascent over a trail that seems to be barely used and is full of loose rocks and branches. Following the trail you'll climb out of NYC DEP land and into John Hand County Park. While the TKT is well marked there are several other trails inside the park that are not marked at all. Eventually, you'll begin to descend into an extremely small parking area. Here you'll turn right onto Blinn Rd and continue approximately 1000 feet and then cross the road into the Teatown portion of the trail. Once you come to Teatown Lake, turn left and follow the blazes to the end of the trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7058962/steam-at-the-bottom-of-the-ravine", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 6.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [588, 208], "alt-change": [809, 783], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 21.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7007828/coles-kettle", "title": "Cole's Kettle", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.17142,-73.673882", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7007828", "info-text": {"description": "Cole's Kettle is a geographic formation from the glacial age. All of the surrounding forest drains into the kettle and then into the ground water for nearby wells. That is why this is such an important feature to keep pristine. If any more development encroached on it, it would threaten not only the wildlife but also the human habitation that depends on the clean groundwater for wells.\r\n\nThough marshy and wet in some places, this loop is usually passable, as boardwalks keep your feet out of the worst of the muck. It's advisable to stash an extra pair of shoes in the car if you're planning on hitting this trail after a heavy rain.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7006836/on-the-cole-kettle-boardwalk", "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 1.3, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [536, 468], "alt-change": [99, 88], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 7.0}},

The Yellow Trail ducks into the woods at about the 3/4 mile point. It is the outer perimeter trail for much of the northern part of the park. \r\n\nThe trail passes the Green Trail, staying to the right and keeping the perimeter. About 1/2 a mile later, it passes the other end of the Green Trail. By then you are on a one mile gradual climb up to the first meadow trail section. \r\n\nAfter the first meadow, you'll pass the Blue Trail entrance on your left. Continue past this trail, and in a short span, you'll pass the Wood Street Access Trail on your right. Continue past that trail, and you'll get to the weather station meadow flats. \r\n\nAbout 2/3rds of the way into the meadow, the Yellow Trail turns left, at the junction with the White Trail which continues along the perimeter. At this point the Yellow Trail joins up with the northern part of the White Trail loop and splits off from there to the left in about 4/10 of a mile. It then parallels the tracks as it ascends away and at about 2.5 miles you reach the Lenape Ridge. Follow the ridge until you reach the end where the trail meets the Minisink Trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7022933/stephanie-and-fred-shuman-running-track", "title": "Stephanie and Fred Shuman Running Track", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=40.784961,-73.966777", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7022933", "info-text": {"description": "Central Park's reservoir is 40 feet deep and holds one billion gallons of water. Built in the 1860s as a temporary water supply for the city, it was decommissioned in 1993.\r\n\nFor years, a seven-foot-high chain-link fence obscured the view of the waterscape, and hikers can catch glimpses of the 1970s-era state of this track in the film \"Marathon Man.\" When scuba divers discovered a piece of the original fence at the bottom of the reservoir, Central Park Conservancy commissioned a steel fence with cast-iron ornamentation, closely resembling the original. The current fence was completed in 2003, stands four feet high, and has opened up breathtaking views of the park and surrounding cityscapes. The track itself was renovated in early 2015 and now consists of a fine gravel over hard packed dirt.\r\n\nWith little to no elevation changes, this short route is enjoyed by walkers and runners of all ages and becomes crowded during the day.\r\n\nThis track is located in Central Park between 85th Street and 96th Street.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Spring", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7024655/central-park", "ratings": {"rating": 4.4, "num_reviewers": 7}, "stats": {"dist": 1.7, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [119, 103], "alt-change": [22, 23], "avg-grade": 0.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

When hiking in the primary direction of travel, the flags will always appear on the right side of the trail. \r\n\nTo access the trail, take the large, obvious foot path into the woods directly behind the playground. After 0.25 miles, you'll begin to see red flag markers on the right side of the trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003869/high-peters-kill-trail", "title": "High Peters Kill Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.744344,-74.197132", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003869", "info-text": {"description": "This trail can be accessed from either Mohonk Preserve at the Coxing Creek parking area or from Minnewaska State Park. There is a fee to park at Minnewaska in an established lot, but hiking is free. Mohonk charges $12/person to use their land. It is more economical to start from the Minnewaska side if you are interested in the terrain and don't intend to use the Mohonk areas.\r\n\nStarting from the Mohonk side, park at the Coxing Creek area. The trail starts at the top left corner of the parking lot (facing the parking lot from the road). The first thing you'll see is the old Enderly family graveyard on your right. The trail continues through a swampy section that crossed on planks. This requires good balance. It crosses a small stream over planks. This stream is later crossed by hopping from rock-to-rock.\r\n\nAfter this crossing there is a split in the trail. King's Highway goes straight up the hill.  High Peters Kill Trail goes left and traverses under the hill. Take the left and continue following the trail as it traverses around the Dicke Barre Wilderness Area. The trail gains the ridge line and crosses past an old ski area. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7004358/millbrook-ridge-trail", "title": "Millbrook Ridge Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.737132,-74.195408", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7004358", "info-text": {"description": "Marked by light blue blazes, the trailhead starts at Trapps Road just beyond the bridge over 44/55 and leads to the summit of Millbrook Mountain.\r\n\nFrom Trapps Bridge, go south on the carriage road for about 300 feet, then find the trailhead (light-blue blazes) on your left. The trail is characterized by angled rock slabs, forests, laurel, and other difficult sections.  \r\n\nThe first great lookout point is called Hawk's Watch. There are great views and it is a nice place to do some birding. A second vantage point is near the summit of the Near Trapps. There is a side trail on the left that climbers often use. It accesses a somewhat dangerous vantage point. A third point of interest is Smedes Cove. This is the boundary between the Near Trapps and the Bayards. \r\n\nThere is a red-marked trail called Bayards Path that tees into this trail from the right just after this saddle in the ridge. The next opportunity to make this a shorter loop is just under two miles into the hike when the Millbrook Cross Trail (red-blazed plus cairns) tees in from the right. \r\n\nPast this point, the trail continues through similar scenery and eventually reaches the summit of Millbrook Mountain. Walking south on Trapps Road, it can be found on the left side.  Follow it as it gradually ascends Millbrook Mountain. It generally follows Coxing Kill.\r\n\nA key highlight of this trail is its history. It was originally used as an agricultural trail. The remains of stone fences can be seen in what was at one time cleared land used for farming.  The landowners would remove the stones left by glaciers and place them in piles, or in fence rows, thus freeing up the land for their use.\r\n\nTake care to be observant of the blue-blazes. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7004536/bonticou-road", "title": "Bonticou Road", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.779355,-74.135391", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7004536", "info-text": {"description": "Bonticou Road begins near the wooden bridge by Mountain Rest Golf Course.
