{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7004634/northeast-trail", "title": "Northeast Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.778879,-74.128519", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7004634", "info-text": {"description": "Northeast Trail (blue blazes) picks up where Woodside Trail leaves off, just north of Mountain Rest Road.  The trail traverses along the eastern edge of Guyot Hill and the golf course.  The first intersection is where Bonticou Road (red blazes) tees in from the left.  \r\n\nThe trail continues with magnificent views of Bonticou Crag appearing soon after passing Bonticou Road.  Northeast Trail continues along the edge of the talus pile and through lightly wooded areas.  It takes a right swing and ascends a small notch in Bonticou Crag.  This notch requires a bit of scrambling and maybe two moves of climbing up with your hands.  Most people in good shape wouldn't think twice about going up this.  Coming down this notch is another story.  Carefully down climb and be sure to have good footing prior to changing hand holds.  From this point on, the trail travels along the eastern slope of the Shawangunk Ridge until it dead ends into Clearwater Road.\r\n\nThe trip along the ridge features incredible views, hiking along rock slabs, and through lightly wooded areas.  Use caution when the rock is wet.  From the dead end into Clearwater Road you can choose to return along the path you took, or turn left on Clearwater Road and link it up with Farm Road to get back to Spring Farm parking area. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7004647/table-rocks-trail", "title": "Table Rocks Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.796623,-74.124477", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7004647", "info-text": {"description": "The blue-blazed Table Rocks Trail runs from Spring Farm parking lot to an area known Table Rocks.  Table Rocks is the product of a huge but slow rock slide that took place over thousands of years as this conglomerate of rock slid downhill to where it now rests.  There are huge crevasses in the rock, some as deep as 105 feet.  Use caution in this area to avoid falling into the crevasses.\r\n\nStarting at the Spring Farm trailhead, follow the blue marked Table Rocks Trail east through an open pasture and across Spring Farm Road.  You'll see Slingerland Pavilion and the barn on the left.  The trail curves right and then enters tight forest.\r\n\nThe next intersection is with red-blazed Cedar Trail as it tees in from the right.  Continue straight through more forest and some brief open meadow as the trail runs under the base of a steep slope. Continue straight into the forest.  \r\n\nFrom this point forward the trail crosses some streams and has some brief scrambling to reach Table Rocks.  Clearwater Road departs to the left soon after the intersection.  Continue straight on Table Rocks Trail.  An old jeep path departs to the right soon afterward and runs to Avery Marsh. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7028632/labyrinth-and-lemon-squeeze", "title": "Labyrinth and Lemon Squeeze", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.767383,-74.154813", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7028632", "info-text": {"description": "This one of a kind \"trail\" is really a scramble through a myriad of huge rock piles followed by a battle with claustrophobia, as you squeeze your way up one final crevice to emerge near Sky Top.\r\n\nThis trail is certainly doable for almost all hikers, but fair warning that there are plenty of places to fall and injure yourself. Excellent shoes are a must, and some even prefer barefoot over the Labyrinth sections towards the beginning. Here one must crawl over, under, and between several ton rocks that is very much like a maze. This section is incredibly rewarding. There are several points where one must pause to think of the safest way to navigate crevices, though, the truly impossible sections wooden ladders are in place to make the route passable.\r\n\nAfter the Labyrinth, continue south through a short singletrack trail and then over more rock, though now exposed to the open skies.\r\n\nFinally, tackle the Lemon Squeeze where you must shimmy your way to a ledge from a crack underneath, with the last section using your arms mores than your legs. When you finally pop out there is a large cliff that overlooks some hills of the Catskill Mountains. Pause here for amazing views before heading to Sky Top via an unpaved road.\r\n\nSky Top itself affords a wonderful 360-degree view of the hills and Mohonk Lake.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7029337/emerge-from-the-lemon-squeeze-for-this-rewarding-view-of-the-surrounding-catskil", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 22}, "stats": {"dist": 0.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1463, 1257], "alt-change": [276, 71], "avg-grade": 12.0, "max-grade": 71.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7096811/genesee-valley-greenway-mount-morris-to-letchworth", "title": "Genesee Valley Greenway: Mount Morris to Letchworth", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.725909,-77.872167", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7096811", "info-text": {"description": "The Genesee Valley Greenway is a rails-to-trails following the old Genesee Valley Canal and the Western New York and Pennsylvania Railroad. It is a work-in-progress, connecting Rochester to Black Creek, with plans to extend the trail to Cuba and possibly Hinsdale.\r\n\nBegin at the parking area in downtown Mount Morris. The Genesee Valley Greenway also heads north from here up to Rochester.\r\n\nTravel south on the trail down to Sonyea about mile 3.8. Cross over the Genesee River, then take a right onto Craig Drive. Turn right at the T and follow the old road as it enters the forest; turn right when the road forks. You're currently in Sonyea State Forest - the creek washed out the railbed, so this is a work-around.\r\n\nAbout mile 6, the trail/road forks; turn left.  After about another mile, the road becomes a more \"real\" road; keep heading south to Presbyterian Road.  Turn right. At the T with Main Street (30A), turn left and continue south. Turn right on Barron Road, then left for a short distance on Creek Road. Turn left again on Dudley Road. About mile 14, you can turn right back onto the Genesee Valley Greenway Trail.  (You can also turn left, but only for a short distance).\r\n\nYou get to be on the trail for only a mile, then turn left on the road to Cooperville Road.  Turn right to pick up the trail (on left) about a mile after you left it.\r\n\nAt mile 19.1, you'll cross Oakland Road and need to go slightly right (uphill) to pick up the trail.  (Going left (downhill) you can see the Oakland Locks, part of the Genesee Valley Canal. A trail goes beside the locks to connect with the Greenway , but the Greenway is an easier ride).\r\n\nAbout mile 22.5, cross the dirt road in Letchworth State Park.  Signs warn that the trail ends a short distance ahead - that's ok.\r\n\nEnjoy the next section of trail - you've been following the Genesee Valley Canal for a while, but now you're sandwiched with the canal on the left and Letchworth Gorge on the right. Occasional peek-a-boo views through the trees let you know not to get close to the edge!\r\n\nLess than a mile after the road, the trail ends at a pile of dirt and signs warning of a landslide area ahead. The landslide tumbled the old rail bed and canal into Letchworth Gorge, so if you want to pick it up, you'll have to go back out to the road and take Rt-436 right into Portageville. From the end of the trail, enjoy views of Deh-ga-ya-soh Falls; you can also see Middle Falls, but be warry of possible cave-ins on the cliff edge.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Historical Significance \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7073448/deh-ga-ya-soh-falls-from-the-genesee-valley-greenway", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 23.4, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1173, 599], "alt-change": [1163, 697], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 11.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025603/escarpment-trail", "title": "Escarpment Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.194445,-74.058343", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025603", "info-text": {"description": "This section of the Long Path ascends Windham High Peak (3,524 ft) from a parking area on Route 23. You'll then get to follow the ridge line up and down a number of smaller peaks before making a steep ascent up Blackhead Mountain (3,940 ft), the 4th highest peak in the Catskills. Parts of the stretch up Blackhead are very steep, but don't require much scrambling past balance. There is a good viewpoint near the summit of Blackhead. \r\n\nThe trail then descends to Dutcher Notch, a shoulder between Blackhead and Stoppel Point. You could continue along the Long Path or descend further on the Colgate Lake Trail to the west of Dutcher Notch Trail to the east. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7025604/kaaterskill-falls-trail", "title": "Kaaterskill Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.191237,-74.070668", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7025604", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts right from a switchback on 23A. Parking is actually just west of the switchback and is fairly clearly marked, but you'll have to hike along the road to the trailhead. During holidays, this parking area could be full. \r\n\nRight at the base of the trail is a decent cascading waterfall. A few switchbacks will take you above this cascade. You'll then gradually gain elevation as you hike along Spruce Creek. This trail gets a lot of use so the trail has morphed into many trails that weave through the forest. \r\n\nWhen you get to the base of the falls you can hang out on the rocks to get some different vantage points. The sun will rise over the top of the falls, so pictures could be washed out and might turn out better much earlier or in the afternoon. We saw many families and all kinds of footwear on this trail, so feel free to bring the kids!\r\n\nA new stone staircase, with roughly 200 steps, was built at the base of the falls. Follow the stairs up to the Escarpment Trail (blue). Stay on the joint Escarpment Trail/Kaaterskill Falls Trail until you reach a fork. Head left at the fork to reach the final viewing platform for the falls.", "features": "Historical Significance \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7060533/katterskill-falls", "ratings": {"rating": 4.3, "num_reviewers": 18}, "stats": {"dist": 1.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2122, 1458], "alt-change": [666, 118], "avg-grade": 13.0, "max-grade": 43.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033598/long-path-section-22-platte-clove-road-to-palenville", "title": "Long Path: Section 22 Platte Clove Road to Palenville", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.176127,-74.030558", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033598", "info-text": {"description": "From the hikers parking lot, turn right onto Route 23a and continue down the road for .4 miles cross the bridge over Kaaterskill Creek and turn left on Malden Ave. Stay on the road and follow a series of blue marks that denote the Long Path Trail. After .9 miles you'll see Freewood restaurant. Shortly turn right onto another short road.   After a few feet, the trail turns onto a woods road and into the forest. From here, the road will start an ascent. \r\n\nAt 1.60 miles point trail  turns right onto a singletrack trail. At 1.80 miles, hikers will be rewarded with Ella's Ledge. While still an accomplishment, the view from the ledge is overgrown. At point 3.1 miles there is a .47 mile long trail leading to Poet's Ledge with beautiful views. Now the trail is almost flat for another 2 miles. You'll see three waterfalls along the way: Hillyer Falls at 3.80 miles,  Wildcat Falls (at 4.3 miles), and finally Buttermilk Falls ( at 4.9 miles). Wildcat and Buttermilk Falls have nice views to the north. \r\n\nAfter the last falls the trail turns south-southwest and begins to ascend again. Some of these ascents are steep and over rocky areas. The trail cuts back and forth to make the climb easier. At 6.3 miles on right hand you'll see a small connector to the snowmobile trail that loops around Kaaterskill High Peak and Round Top Mountain. You go straight for another 3.5 miles on the Long Path Trail (blue mark) to reach a parking lot on Platte Clove Rd.\r\n\nThe  Huckleberry Point Trail turnoff is located 1 mile before the parking lot, which is a popular side trip if you have the time. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031869/jackrabbit-trail-aka-craigwood-trails-connector", "title": "Jackrabbit Trail (AKA Craigwood Trails Connector)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.259753,-73.949269", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031869", "info-text": {"description": "While this trail serves as a great downhill treat after a few laps on the Craig Wood Trails, your first encounter with it will be as it smacks you in the face with its steep grades, loose surface, and punishing final climb. Nonetheless, don't be discouraged \u2013 it is well worth the singletrack Valhalla that is to come.\r\n\nTo reach the start of this trail, hikers must park at the Roadside Parking Area off River Road, cross over the road to Bird Song Lane (just north of the dirt pull-off where you parked) and follow the gravel doubletrack up hill to a junction in a few hundred feet. At the junction, continue straight, paying little attention to the confusing permitted-use signs in the area (you're more than welcome to be here) and instead following the signs for the Jackrabbit Trail. After climbing just a short while longer, keep your eyes peeled for an aluminum gate on the right side of the road and a small passage to its right side. You're here! \r\n\nPast the gate, the Jackrabbit Trail descends gently through verdant deciduous forests before crossing a bridge over a small creek and beginning a climb in earnest. Generally, the trail throws steep grades and a loose tread your way in a tiered climb-flat-climb sequence through this section.\r\n\nYou'll know you've reached the top of the tiered climb when the hill begins to fall away from you to a creek on your left side. At this point, the trail turns steeply downhill, descending a narrow, occasionally rutted singletrack over loose melon-sized rocks to a second bridge over the creek from before.\r\n\nHead up the steep gravel doubletrack for a short-but-painful hundred yards before the trail ends at a break in the trees and the signage for Back Nine points you to the left.\r\n\nOn the way back down the Jackrabbit Trail (AKA Craigwood Trails Connector), be careful near the last bridge crossing near the end of the trail, as it is shady and the wood stays slick long after wet weather.", "features": "Fall Colors", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1934, 1770], "alt-change": [177, 13], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 18.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7094852/finger-lakes-trail-segment-18", "title": "Finger Lakes Trail: Segment 18", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.447054,-76.254364", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7094852", "info-text": {"description": "The long and rolling Finger Lakes Trail gives users a remote, wild experience compared to many of the surrounding popular trails.\r\n\nAfter following some roads to Hammond Hill State Forest, the trail shares markers with the forest's Yellow 4 (Y4) trail for about a mile, then continues to Red 2 (R2). After crossing Hartford Slaterville Road, continue south over rolling terrain. The Kimmie lean-to is a short ways off the trail at mile 7.3 as it makes a sharp right turn after descending into a valley. At mile 8.3 the trail meets Robinson Hollow Rd. In order to pick the trail back up, follow the road south, turn west on State Hwy 79 for about 2000 ft, then find the trail on the left.\r\n\nOther road crossings are fairly straight forward until McGrath Rd at mile 13.8. Follow the road south, crossing County Rd 115 and entering Shindagin State Forest. The Shindagin lean-to is at mile 16.7. Shindagin has its own network of trails that the FLC traverses after a steep climb up to the heart of the state forest. Keep moving generally west, and a steep descent will mark the exit from that trail system.\r\n\nAfter crossing White Church Rd, turn north onto the Ridgeway Trail, an old rail trail at mile 20.7. Follow this path for about half a mile before picking up the Finger Lakes Trail again on the left. Meeting Ridgeway Rd at mile 22, turn left onto the road, followed by an immediate right turn onto County Road 119 and another left onto Eastman Hill Rd. Find the trail again at mile 22.4 on the left as it enters Danby State Forest. Climb to the top of Eastman Hill, then descend, meeting and following Heisey Rd along the way, until meeting NY 9. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7033397/scarface-mountain", "title": "Scarface Mountain", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.298239,-74.083325", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7033397", "info-text": {"description": "Start by singing in at the trailhead and then head south to soon cross a railroad track. After about a half-mile, you'll traverse a wooden footbridge over Ray Brook. The trail is so thickly cushioned with pine needles that you'll wonder if anyone else has been on the trail for some time. The first 1.6 miles are through a thick, moss-covered woods. \r\n\nAt 1.6 miles, the trail takes a sharp, well-marked left. Continue on the trail a short ways before connecting with a small creek. The trail begins to take on grade here.\r\n\nAt the 2.0 mile mark, cross the brook and begin up a steeper grade. It's a continuous uphill from this point on. At 2.75 miles, the trail gets even steeper with some occasional small rock scrambling and plenty of mud. \r\n\nBy 3.0 miles you're rewarded with a view of the mountains around you. There is a small clearing on a rock face that provides a nice view and a good place to take a break. Many think this is the summit, but you're not quite there. If you came for a view, you might as well head back now. If you want to claim that you climbed the mountain, you must continue.\r\n\nFor the final 0.6 miles, hikers follow the ridge at the top of the mountain, where you can see the sky between the trees when you look both left and right. A very gentle rolling trail will eventually lead you to a rock in the middle of the woods. You'll see a round marker that says \"Scarface Mtn\" on it. You have reached the summit! Sadly however, there's no view to top it all off.\r\n\nOn your return to the car, the mud and rocks from before conspire to make your last memory a painful one, but if you take your time, it is very manageable.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7033980/view-from-the-rock-cleaning-at-3-miles", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 3.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3088, 1595], "alt-change": [1552, 115], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 37.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7040970/ampersand-mountain-trail", "title": "Ampersand Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.251254,-74.239605", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7040970", "info-text": {"description": "The distance on this trail is only three miles to the summit, and six miles out and back. It is one of the few mountains in the 'daks that offers an amazing 360-degree view after only a few miles of hiking.\r\n\nThe trailhead is located across Route 3 from where you park. There appears to be a trail at the parking area, but that goes to some camping areas in the opposite direction of the mountain.\r\n\nYou'll see a register to sign in and red markers to follow.\r\n\nLike most of the ADK trails, you start with a nice casual hike on low grades through hardwood forest. The trail crosses a few brooks, has a small wooden bridge, and even some wood planks to hike on in the first few miles.\r\n\nAt 1.5 miles, you'll see the mountain directly in front of you as you begin to climb some moderate elevation. At 2.0 miles, you'll begin climbing a very steep set of rock stairs all of the way to the summit. You'll also have a few rock scrambles and some amazing views of rock ledges hanging over the trail. \r\n\nJust shy of the summit, the trail becomes open rock and is marked by yellow paint on the rocks. Be sure to follow the markers to avoid erosion. The hike is not long from here, and you'll soon reach the summit clad with three survey markers on it. The summit views are amazing in all four seasons. The wind can be very strong, so be prepared with extra layers.\r\n\nYou may also follow the yellow-blazed trail beyond the summit to find a plaque dedicated to the Hermit of Ampersand.", "features": "Cave \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "All Clear"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7063934/top-of-ampersand-mountain-viewing-one-of-the-saranac-lakes", "ratings": {"rating": 4.8, "num_reviewers": 8}, "stats": {"dist": 2.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3336, 1579], "alt-change": [1793, 36], "avg-grade": 13.0, "max-grade": 70.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7009634/rooster-comb-trail", "title": "Rooster Comb Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.185469,-73.786935", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7009634", "info-text": {"description": "Starting from the Rooster Comb Trailhead, follow the trail over a boardwalk through marshy ground to reach a junction with a loop trail around a small pond (the local elementary school kids built it long ago, so don't strain yourself too hard looking for beavers.) The trail will continue around the pond to the west, and will quickly depart into the beautiful deciduous forests typical of the region. \r\n\nAfter a flat start, don't be surprised when the trail begins to steepen. Roostercomb Peak is but a small barrier for many hikers seeking access to higher peaks. The trail will zigzag upwards and move over a combination of loamy soil and rocks. Watch your step, especially in the fall when leaves make the trail slick.\r\n\nAfter passing a few signed junctions, you'll reach a junction with the Flume Brook Trail and the Hedgehog Trail near 1.9 miles in. Head right on the Roostercomb Trail to continue to the summit, but otherwise, you can continue on the Hedgehog Trail to experience more of the High Peaks' famous Great Range. For a look at the whole route, check out the Featured Hike: Adirondack Great Range.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 2.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2770, 1026], "alt-change": [1751, 7], "avg-grade": 15.0, "max-grade": 39.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7009669/adirondack-range-trail", "title": "Adirondack Range Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.14475,-73.834905", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7009669", "info-text": {"description": "The Range Trail connects three iconic Adirondack high peaks; Upper Wolfjaw, Armstrong and Gothics. While not for the faint of heart, the effort that you put into this trail is certainly worth the views and the bragging rights. \r\n\nAs with many Adirondack trails, don't expect too many switchbacks, and much of your elevation gain will be made in scrambles up technical, rocky faces. Treacherous even in the best of conditions, the trails deteriorate in the rain, leaving them muddy and slick. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7009682/state-range-trail", "title": "State Range Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.126356,-73.866804", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7009682", "info-text": {"description": "Summiting Saddleback and Basin mountains, and leading to the junction for the trail leading to Haystack, the State Range trail is technically difficult, and will challenge even experienced hikers. \r\n\nGaining and losing elevation quickly, the trail isn't easy on the joints. However, the views from Basin and Saddleback, as well as the feeling of accomplishment can't be beat. \r\n\nThe trail ascends and descends through the upper reaches of the Adirondack forests, and you'll be surrounded by thick growths of pine trees for the duration of the trail. As with most Adirondack trails, expect plenty of roots and granite, and don't be surprised to see wooden planks in the trail- they help maintain integrity when things get wet!", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4833, 3982], "alt-change": [1603, 1508], "avg-grade": 21.0, "max-grade": 63.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7009856/mount-haystack-trail", "title": "Mount Haystack Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.112459,-73.901937", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7009856", "info-text": {"description": "The route up Haystack is incredibly technical no matter which way you choose to ascend from. From either direction, the trail reaches the granite that the bald peak is composed of, and the hiker has no choice aside from \"up\". Yellow paint will guide your way, and make you feel a little bit like Dorothy (though you're definitely not in Kansas anymore). \r\n\nBecause Haystack is bald, the views of Lake Colden, and even Elk Lake are spectacular, and on clear days visitors can see quite a ways. While exhausting, the trail keeps things exciting, and the paint is generally in good shape. \r\n\nIf you ascend from the northeast, be prepared that the summit of Little Haystack can provide a false sense of accomplishment, and though the distance between the two is short, the elevation gain occurs all at once.", "features": "Views \u00b7 Waterfall", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7040119/little-haystack-and-view-northeast-through-johns-brook-valley-to-big-slide-shoul", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 1.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4882, 3849], "alt-change": [280, 1041], "avg-grade": 25.0, "max-grade": 46.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7026792/mount-skylight-trail", "title": "Mount Skylight Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.105519,-73.93133", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7026792", "info-text": {"description": "To get to this trail you'll need to hike a long ways along either the Calamity Brook Trail or the Elk Lake to Mount Marcy Trail. Which ever way you take, you'll have to continue all the way to the Four Corners Trail which is on the shoulder between Mount Marcy and Mount Skylight. \r\n\nFrom Four Corners, turn south. The trail will quickly become steep. The trail can be a slog and is heavily-wooded at first. However, it at least isn't far to the rewarding parts. There will be some rocky areas with clearings that will present amazing views of Mount Marcy. \r\n\nFrom the summit, you'll have 360\u00b0 views. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7026946/mt-marcy-summit-trail", "title": "Mt. Marcy Summit Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.105519,-73.93133", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7026946", "info-text": {"description": "This route is a classic Adirondack route, summiting a 46'er and featuring some of the most rugged trail in the area. Mt. Marcy is one of the more famous peaks, and those wishing to complete a trip along the Great Range won't want to miss this peak. \r\n\nStarting from the Four Corners intersection with the Calamity Brook Trail, Elk Lake to Mount Marcy Trail, and the Mount Skylight Trail, you'll quickly gain elevation. Like most trails in the area, there will be a few boggy spots where the trail traverses flat portions. Muddy boots are a must, unless you happen to be visiting during an especially dry year. The beginning of the trail is heavily forested, and there are plenty of small pines that line the trail. \r\n\nAs you continue on your way to the summit, you'll come across a variety of rock slabs, many of them wet, that must be navigated. These portions are steep, tricky, and can play with the head of even the most intrepid hiker. The going will likely be slow as finding the best way to negotiate tricky sections will take some time. As you gain elevation on the steep trail some amazing views will begin to open as the trees thin out. Eventually, you'll be completely clear of trees on a final, huge rock slab. Try to look ahead to the next cairn to keep going in a logical direction as the rock slab more or less masks a clear trail. The slab is fairly steep, but you can hike right up it if you stick to a good path. \r\n\nHowever, once you reach the mostly bald summit of Mount Marcy, your arduous journey will be well worthwhile. Just make sure to dress in layers! Even when it's a bit muggy lower down, the summit of Marcy sees brisk winds.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7027865/the-final-rock-slab-section-of-mount-marcy-leads-to-awesome-views-from-the-summi", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [5216, 4382], "alt-change": [834, 0], "avg-grade": 22.0, "max-grade": 42.0}},

The trail leaves the east shore of Lake Colden and starts immediately uphill. The steep climb is steady with plenty of rocks and roots to overcome. At 0.6 miles, the trail takes a sharp left turn. This turn is easily missed, so if you find that the trail disappears, stop and turn back! After this 0.6 miles, the trail gets even steeper until you crest a false summit. Continue along the ridge with great views of Lake Colden, Algonquin, Iroquois, and Wright Peak to the west. There are some great views from the summit. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7069073/seymour-mountain-herd-path", "title": "Seymour Mountain Herd Path", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.175909,-74.169042", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7069073", "info-text": {"description": "Starting at the Corey's Road trailhead, take the Blueberry Foot Trail to the Ward Brook Truck Trail (both of which are very flat, easy trails). It is roughly 5.2 miles to the Ward Brook Lean-To, which has an outhouse, unlike Blueberry Lean-To. The herd path is marked by a cairn on the right side of the Ward Brook Truck Trail 0.1 miles past Ward Brook Lean-To.\r\n\nThe bottom part of the trail is a moderate incline that tends to be muddy. The top part is wet even in August and features many difficult rock faces that need to be climbed. As hard as it is to get up, getting down safely is much trickier.\r\n\nThe trail starts to open up with limited views to the north as you continue to climb, so you can tell when you are getting closer to the top even without an altimeter. Just below the summit is a tiered ledge just off the path to the right (west) with a fantastic view of the Seward Range and the Ampersand Range. The true summit (complete with sign) is 0.1 miles farther on. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7076606/seward-range-off-trail-route", "title": "Seward Range Off-Trail Route", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.181301,-74.178699", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7076606", "info-text": {"description": "The Blueberry lean-to is about 0.1 miles west of the junction of the Blueberry Foot Trail and the Blueberry Horse Trail. The cairn on the right (south) side of the trail is about 0.1 miles beyond that junction. The path can be difficult to follow until it starts climbing--many muddy spots until then also. \r\n\nA few tenths of a mile in the trail starts ascending up a rocky stream bed that may not be dry in the spring. From here it gets gradually steeper, with the terrain changing from large rocks and roots to granite slabs. Very near the top of Seward is a headwall that cannot be ascended by an average height hiker without equipment, and the trail follows the wall until it gets low enough to crawl over. This is basically the summit of Seward.\r\n\nSouth of the summit is a nice outlook over towards a subpeak of Seward, Donaldson, and Emmons. The descent down the southern face of Seward is steep with loose rocks, and likely not easy to climb up either. The trail is slightly to the east of the ridgeline.\r\n\nIn the last 0.1 miles north of the summit of Donaldson views towards Seward open up, and there is a cairn marking the junction with Calkins Brook Trail , another well-defined herd path. Just shy of the summit of Donaldson is an outlook to the west featuring the Ampersand Range. The true summit is a boulder on the east side of the trail.\r\n\nIt is 1.3 miles from the summit of Donaldson to Emmons. Donaldson's southern summit is almost as high as its northern (true) summit. The trail is gentler between Donaldson and Emmons than between Seward and Donaldson. There are still a few scrambles going up Emmons, though.\r\n\nAt the totally viewless summit of Emmons the trail just stops--no branching paths to view points or anything, it just ends.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 4.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4359, 2109], "alt-change": [2719, 771], "avg-grade": 17.0, "max-grade": 47.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7096701/cliff-mountain", "title": "Cliff Mountain", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.107705,-73.960974", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7096701", "info-text": {"description": "Cliff is an unmaintained (unmarked) though very easy to follow herd path. Once you make the 7 mile hike in typically done via the Calamity Brook Trail take the Mt. Redfield Trail for a couple hundred feet, there is a tree remarking which route is Cliff and which route is Redfield (sorta hard to spot). Take a right and the trail immediately gets really sloppily muddy for about 0.3 miles.  \r\n\nAfter that you'll reach a smaller technical sub blocky area to scramble over. There is 1 more smaller one and the next 3 require some technical moves that while aren't too difficult could prove dangerous. At a certain point you'll feel like you've peaked and the trail starts going down hill to the point where you feel like you've already peaked. Keep going to reach the summit until you reach the summit sign. \r\n\nNear the top you'll get some views of Colden Mountain, Mount Marcy, and Skylight peaking behind the trees if you turn around. Not much of a view at the top, but if you want to get the ADK 46 its not a bad hike, and often done with Mount Redfield. It is a long day from the Upperworks Trailhead (just under 19 miles). There are plenty of lean-tos and camping spots on Calamity Brook Trail though.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7073269/view-of-grey-mtn-mt-marcy-peaking-out-behind-grey-and-great-views-of-mt-skylight", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3953, 3326], "alt-change": [743, 117], "avg-grade": 16.0, "max-grade": 54.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036326/street-and-nye-trail", "title": "Street and Nye Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.183788,-73.972886", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036326", "info-text": {"description": "While Street Mountain is considered a trail-less 46'er, there is a trail that is well worn and easy to follow for the most part. From the Heart Lake parking lot, follow a gravel trail around the north end of the lake until you reach a sign that states \"Old Nye Ski Trail.\" Follow this to the right and after about 1.5 miles you'll reach Indian Pass Brook. Here the ski trail comes to an end, but a foot path continues on the other side. This stream is wide and easy to cross in the summer. However, if hiking in the spring, be prepared for a difficult crossing due to swift and high water. The other issue crossing this stream is picking up the trail once across. There are several locations to cross. This is due to people looking for the best place to cross, which depends on water levels. If crossing at the first point you can access the stream, turn right once across and follow the faint trail until the trail turns left and travels uphill.\r\n\nAnother 0.5 miles from the stream crossing there is another stream crossing, but this one is easy and not very wide. After this point, the trail climbs steadily along a rocky and root-covered trail. At about mile 3, you come to a trail junction with Nye Mountain Trail. This is actually carved into a tree.\r\n\nTurn left to the summit of Street Mountain. This is the most enjoyable section because the trail travels through rocks and trees covered in many shades of green moss. There is no view from the actual summit\u2014only a sign. A trail continues to possible viewpoints but nothing definitive.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7036750/trail-above-3500-feet-is-rough-but-lined-with-green-moss-beautiful", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 3.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4182, 2013], "alt-change": [2265, 323], "avg-grade": 13.0, "max-grade": 46.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036327/nye-mountain-trail", "title": "Nye Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.185379,-74.02188", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036327", "info-text": {"description": "This is a short trail from the trail junction with the Street Mountain Trail. Nye is considered a required ascent to join the 46'er club, although it is not over 4000 feet. It is designated as a separate mountain from Street because there is more than 0.5 miles between the two summits. The trail is not marked but easy to follow.\r\n\nAlong the way, expect the tread to be rocky and covered with roots, but not nearly as steep as its neighbor, Street Mountain. It's worth the extra time if you just made an ascent of Street, however, there is no view from the summit, only a sign that you have arrived.", "features": "Fall Colors", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7036749/trail-direction-carved-into-tree-for-street-mountain-to-the-left-and-nye-mountai", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3899, 3817], "alt-change": [81, 6], "avg-grade": 8.0, "max-grade": 21.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7068768/cold-brook-trail", "title": "Cold Brook Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.14669,-74.023506", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7068768", "info-text": {"description": "Starting from the Indian Pass Trail: there is a signpost right where this trail should lead off of the Indian Pass Trail that will not mention Mt Marshall or point in the direction of this trail, which is marked by a cairn that is slightly hidden on the opposite side of the trail from the signpost. This is the beginning of the Cold Brook Trail.\r\n\nIt ascends gradually at first, becoming steeper as it makes its way up a narrow gorge, crossing the river several times. This path is not marked or maintained, so be sure you have sharpened your route-finding skills--they will be needed. \r\n\nThere are many downed trees, even when the trail leaves the gorge, and it is very overgrown in general.\r\n\nJust before the height-of-land, there is a cairn and a spur trail on the right that lead up Mt Marshall. This spur trail has the same conditions as the Cold Brook Trail.\r\n\nPast the height-of-land, a few tenths of a mile beyond the spur trail, is the wreck of a Piper from 1969. It can be seen from the trail, but there is also an obvious path to it. The solo pilot survived and walked back to safety.\r\n\nDown towards Lake Colden is very steep in places, with large rocks and areas of standing water.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3875, 2547], "alt-change": [1329, 1029], "avg-grade": 16.0, "max-grade": 30.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7026791/elk-lake-to-mount-marcy-trail", "title": "Elk Lake to Mount Marcy Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.020809,-73.828033", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7026791", "info-text": {"description": "This long trail is a great alternate route for those looking to enjoy more of the High Peaks on the way to Mount Marcy. At the trailhead, there is a moderate parking area that has room for between 10-20 cars. \r\n\nAs you start out on your journey, the going will be fairly easy. In this first section, the trail follows an old road trace so there is often room to hike two abreast. The trail is still rocky, so do watch your ankles! You'll pass through a mixed forest of birch, beech, and other Adirondack natives that will shade your way. Especially in the summer months, the shade is much appreciated. \r\n\nYou'll cross over both Nellie and Guideboard Brook. It's worth noting that stopping to fill up water at Guideboard Brook is recommended. There are bridges over both bodies of water, and you won't have to worry about getting your boots wet... Yet. \r\n\nAs you continue on, the track will narrow. You'll have to work your way up and over a ridge, and while not overly steep, this initial climb makes a noticeable change from the flat hiking that you've been enjoying. After reaching a brief peak, you'll enjoy a brief descent into the most notable part of this trail. At the bottom of the slope, you'll need to make your way through the infamous Marcy Swamp. \r\n\nWhile the segment leading through Marcy Swamp is short, it is time-consuming, and aside from the novelty of negotiating a swamp, mostly Type 2 fun. There are blazes and many log bridges spanning the wettest sections, but you'll likely still leave with muddy boots. The vegetation is mostly lower growing here, and the sun can be fierce in the summer months. Combined with the humidity of this section, you'll be happy to see the other side. \r\n\nOnce you reach the other side of the swamp, you'll begin a slow and steady ascent towards Panther Gorge and Mount Marcy. The vegetation transitions sharply, and the willows of the swamp will transition to a mixed forest of both deciduous and evergreen trees. Though you'll be making your way up, the path is quite pleasant as most of the tread is softened by needle-fall. As you continue to gain elevation, the deciduous trees will thin, and the forest will become predominantly evergreen. \r\n\nAbout 2.5 miles from the swamp, the trail will begin a steep uptick, and you'll really notice the elevation gain. This is the final push towards Panther Gorge. Commonly regarded as one of the most beautiful locations in the High Peaks (though those partial to Avalanche Lake may disagree) Panther Gorge makes for an excellent place to stop. With a thundering fall located near the trail and sweeping views to the south and west, the effort will be well worthwhile. Continue past a lean-to reach the Four Corners intersection and continue on your way.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.5, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 10.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4365, 2012], "alt-change": [3055, 768], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 41.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7029583/randallswards-outer-loop", "title": "Randall's/Wards Outer Loop", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=40.785247,-73.935354", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7029583", "info-text": {"description": "Wards and Randalls Islands are separated from Manhattan by the Harlem River, from Queens by the East River and Hell Gate, and from the Bronx by the Bronx Kill. Formerly separated by Little Hell Gate channel, the two islands were filled in by the early 1960s and now host over 400 acres of parkland in addition to city infrastructure.\r\n\nBeginning from the 103rd Street Footbridge (1951), head south on Wards Island along the Harlem River, viewing Manhattan's upper East Side to your right. At the bottom of the island, the trail passes under the RFK Bridge (formerly Triborough; 1936) and Hell Gate Bridge (1917). Between the two bridges, a native plant garden is located to your right. Across the street, on top the hill to your left, is the island's urban farm. The trail continues underneath Hell Gate bridge where paving ends. \r\n\nTo exit the under-bridge path you'll pass through a gate. The trail starts/stops here due to the existence of the Wards Island Water Pollution Control Plant (1937), which serves over 1 million city residents with a capacity of 275 million US gallons per day (in addition to a telltale aroma). Continue following the direction of the bridge until the street turns toward the left; here you'll make a right to return underneath Hell Gate Bridge where a stretch of paved path resumes. While you traverse this section, you are crossing the original boundary between Wards and Randalls Islands.\r\n\nAt the end of this path, follow the mulched trail on your left. You'll return back to the street, passing a bus stop. Again, continue via a stretch of sidewalk in the direction of Hell Gate Bridge. You'll cross entrance roads leading to the water treatment plant and the NYC Fire Department's training academy on your right. After crossing, you'll see that the paved trail resumes beneath Hell Gate Bridge.\r\n\nFollow the trail a short distance until you see a paved footpath exiting to your right. From here, you'll circle counterclockwise along the Sunken Meadow Loop, passing by the Tennis Academy on your right and numerous baseball diamonds to your left (this corner of Randalls Island hosts 31 diamonds). Past the Tennis Academy you'll see one baseball diamond to your right; here, veer to the right to head up a small hill. This area hosts native grasses and has a small pull off at the top. In addition to a view of the East River, at this location you can turn around to see some of the Fire Academy's buildings; a sharp eye will spot burn marks trailing out from some of the windows.The academy features a subway tunnel with tracks and two subway cars, a helicopter pad, a replica ship, and multiple buildings designed to simulate the different types of structures encountered within the city limits (most of this is out of sight).\r\n\nContinuing to circle along the outermost path, you'll begin to head west along the Bronx Kill. This shallow straight delineates the border between Manhattan and the Bronx. After crossing under Hell Gate bridge, you'll reach the RFK/Triborough; cross underneath and continue along the sidewalk/trail.\r\n\nAs you follow the sidewalk while looping around the top of Randalls Island, you'll be passing more baseball diamonds to your right. Just before crossing under the overpass, on your right is the NYPD Harbor Unit marina. Keep to your right to follow the Harlem River Path.\r\n\nContinuing south, Icahn Stadium (2005) is on your left. South of the stadium you'll encounter a roundabout area where you'll turn right to pass across Little Hell Gate bridge through a salt marsh, crossing the original boundary between the two islands. \r\n\nTurning right after exiting the marsh, you'll pass through a wooded area and the Water's Edge Garden, featuring native plants and a view of East Harlem across the river. You'll pass a small horse stable on your left before completing the loop.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7030373/view-across-harlem-river-towards-e-117th-st-from-end-of-waters-edge-garden-path", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 4.9, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [29, 4], "alt-change": [68, 70], "avg-grade": 1.0, "max-grade": 2.0}},

Entering the trail from White Street or the B-Loop Trail intersection, it gradually climbs through pine forest which quickly transitions to hardwoods. In less than 0.75 miles, the grade becomes mostly level before transitioning to a long, twisting mostly downhill section.  \r\n\nAs the grade begins to level off at the bottom of the long downhill, a pond will eventually come into view. Adding to the excitement in this section are several hairpin turns and a few minor obstacles.  \r\n\nFrom the low point of this steep descent, the trail traverses above a steep drop-off before climbing moderately. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031902/peaks-2-and-3-loop", "title": "Peaks #2 and #3 Loop", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.925519,-75.311412", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031902", "info-text": {"description": "The outbound section descends northwest from the top of Tassel Hill Peak #1 into a fairly level valley and eventually traverses up an easy grade along the shoulder of Peak #2. Once the Peak #2 high point is reached, the trail follows the ridge for a while before dropping into the next valley. \r\n\nFrom the valley bottom, the trail begins to climb again and after the height of land is reached, the trail eventually breaks into an open grassy area. The open area is the highest point along the ridge and in Oneida County. Views looking north to the Mohawk Valley are excellent.\r\n\nTo hike the return loop, continue northwest to where the wide grassy area begins to narrow down to doubletrack and look for a trail entering the woods on your left. Once in the woods, the trails turns back to the south and you'll soon encounter a fun switchback section that twists back and forth across a fairly steep ravine.\r\n\nAfter the ravine section, the trail descends and eventually levels out. Eventually, the trail begins a moderate climb as it angles back towards the outbound trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031904/a-loop-trail", "title": "A-Loop Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.915665,-75.325677", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031904", "info-text": {"description": "This is typically the first trail most hikers hit when hiking the Tassel Hill trail network. It starts out with a moderate climb through pine forest leading to a ravine crossing with a narrow bridge. Moderate climbing resumes as the trail pulls away from the ravine in open hardwood forest. \r\n\nAfter a short off-camber uphill section, the trail levels out for a bit then transitions to a fun section with alternating short climbs and descents. The trail returns to a pine forest and crosses two shallow bridged ravines. After the second bridge, the trail resumes climbing through the pine forest where several rock piles are eventually encountered. \r\n\nThe top of the climb is reached as the forest transitions back to hardwoods. The final section from the top of the climb is all downhill. This final section of the trail is the most technical with several steep ravines and many rocks where you'll want to watch your footing.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.8, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1724, 1540], "alt-change": [283, 234], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 19.0}},

There are no facilities or water sources on this hike. \r\n\nUpon intersecting the orange markers of the Great Eastern Trail (GET) you can turn west towards Erwin Hollow Road which follows a reliable water source, or continue east/north and you'll eventually arrive at Amelia's Pond.\r\n\nThis trail section is well-used by day hikers and trail runners. The trail is compacted soil, well marked and well maintained. There are a few spots of rise and fall but nothing steep enough to warrant hand holds. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7006702/casino-trail", "title": "Casino Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.493402,-73.95986", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7006702", "info-text": {"description": "While traveling primarily through Hudson Highlands State Park Preserve, this trail actually starts from Mount Beacon Park. If you can, try to hit this trail on a weekday, as it gets incredibly busy on the weekends. \r\n\nFrom the start, follow a nice gravel path to a metal staircase. After this, the trail gets steep and rocky. While it's very wide, it's no longer a road due to erosion. There are many trails leading up the steep ridge, but the park service has done a poor job designating which trail for you to take. If you're afraid of getting lost, be sure to follow the red blazes, and bring the Hiking Project mobile app with you to quell any concerns.\r\n\nOnce you arrive at the old casino, be sure to take time to check out the ruins. Much of what is remaining is a foundation, but the old cable house has walls intact and is interesting to photograph. Be aware: this is a very large viewpoint with many people, so you might have to wait patiently for your chance to take a nice photo. \r\n\nMost people turn back from the viewpoint unless you are making a loop through the park. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7031845/osborn-loop", "title": "Osborn Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.338525,-73.945631", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7031845", "info-text": {"description": "Although the name of this trail is Osborn Loop, the trail itself is not a full loop. It starts on the Appalachian Trail only to end four miles later at a point farther up the Appalachian Trail. By using the AT as a connector, you are able to make a full loop hike.\r\n\nTo access the blue-blazed Osborn Loop, start on the Appalachian Trail where it crosses South Mountain Pass Road and follow its steep terrain to the trail junction with the Osborn Loop. Once you've made it to the junction, the actual Osborn Loop is a piece of cake.\r\n\nWhile easy and smooth-treaded throughout its entire length, don't expect great views from this trail. Instead, enjoy the feelings of seclusion and solitude it brings as you meander through its dense forest cover. \r\n\nUpon reaching the end of the trail, you can head south on the AT to return to your car.", "features": "Wildflowers", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7032597/at-the-end-of-the-osborn-loop-trail-you-can-jump-right-back-on-the-appalachian-t", "ratings": {"rating": 3.8, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 4.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [917, 544], "alt-change": [555, 470], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 21.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7032675/fishkill-ridge-trail", "title": "Fishkill Ridge Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.496961,-73.949503", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7032675", "info-text": {"description": "The Fishkill Ridge Trail is almost always completed as a loop by simply hiking the Wilkinson Memorial Trail and the Dozer Junction Trail to complete the loop. The parking area at the trailhead is only big enough for three cars. Arrive early! It is in a residential area and local police write tickets to those parking on the road. I saw quite a few on cars when I returned to the trailhead!\r\n\nStart up the paved road, pass a water storage facility, to the end where the trail begins (there are white markers along the road as well. The trail is gradual at this point but after you pass Dry Creek Falls, the trail gets very steep. \r\n\nYou eventually top out on Lamb Hill which offers great views of the town of Beacon and the Hudson River. Continue on until the trail drops down to what appears to be a fire road. This is the Dozer Junction Trail. Just off to the right, you'll see the remains of an old bulldozer. Cross of this fire road and make an immediate right turn so you are paralleling the Dozer Trail.\r\n\nThe Fishkill Ridge Trail begins to turn away and uphill past several great view points on the Hudson Valley and Hudson River looking further south. Continuing on the trail, it meanders through the forest until you reach a big clearing on top of Bald Hill. The trail then steeply descends and will turn back along an easy overgrown forest road. Continue straight on this until you meet up with the Wilkinson Memorial Trail and the end of the Fishkill Ridge Trail.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7033818/remnants-of-an-old-rocking-chair-along-the-ridge", "ratings": {"rating": 3.7, "num_reviewers": 7}, "stats": {"dist": 4.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1504, 429], "alt-change": [1450, 750], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 79.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039606/all-in-trail", "title": "All-In Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.364611,-73.800562", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039606", "info-text": {"description": "This lollipop loop on the east side of Hardy Road is a blast, and well worth the climb. The climb is steady with a few short breaks along the way. There are a couple rock step-up/downs in the switchbacks on the stick part of the lollipop, and range from from 2' to 6' in height. The upper loop is fun in both directions, with some filtered views of Whiteface from the upper ledges.\r\n\nThe climate here is somewhat unique for the area. All-In Trail follows a ridge that sits squarely in the rain-shadow of Whiteface at a relatively low elevation, meaning it's significantly drier and warmer than surrounding areas. It's not uncommon to come from Lake Placid where it might be cloudy and raining to find Hardy Road dry and sunny. This trail tends to dry out very quickly, and is one of the first to be ready in the early season and after a rainy spell. The upper ledges are a great place to stop, have a beverage, and recover from the climb.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.9, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1685, 952], "alt-change": [748, 317], "avg-grade": 7.0, "max-grade": 15.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039137/tinker-falls-trail", "title": "Tinker Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.780084,-76.035562", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039137", "info-text": {"description": "While you'd never know it driving past the pulloff for this trail on an otherwise-typical country road in Central New York, this trail leads you a short distance to one of the most beautiful and unique waterfalls in the region. Tinker Falls is fantastic in any season, as the warmer months bring cascading water and beautiful leaf-filtered sunlight, and the winter brings continual construction of an amphitheater of ice (bring your camera)!\r\n\nFrom the pull-offs on each side of the road, pass a kiosk to follow the creek past gorgeous hardwood forests. The trail climbs along its length, although you'll be so flush with anticipation to reach the falls that you'll hardly notice it. \r\n\nUpon reaching an opening in the forest, enjoy the gorgeous Tinker Falls as it flows in a curtain of water (or ice) in front of you. Those who'd like to, can easily climb the scree at the base of the falls to reach the cave behind and enjoy a different perspective.\r\n\nWhen you've had your fill of the falls, simply return the way you came, or continue up the hillside left of the falls to reach a junction with the regional Finger Lakes Trail.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Waterfall \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7038245/after-a-light-summer-rain-water-dribbles-over-tinker-falls-in-truxton-ny", "ratings": {"rating": 4.8, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 0.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1452, 1291], "alt-change": [162, 0], "avg-grade": 11.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7035161/east-setauket", "title": "East Setauket", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=40.907035,-73.090058", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7035161", "info-text": {"description": "The East Setauket trail is just over 15 miles of singletrack trail. The main loop is approximately 5 miles and has some tight spots, switchbacks, moguls, and climbs.\r\n\nThe 10 miles of diamond are the most intense that Long Island has to offer in terms of climbing. The downhill gradient is the steepest for any official Long Island trail that you'll find. \r\n\nWhen taking the main loop you'll cross over an open field where you can see power-lines as far as you can see. You cross over and continue on the main and loop around into the first off-shoot trail known as BJ's way. You do that and then go back on the main and the next off-shoot is Wild Laurel followed by Switcharoo and then back to Wild Laurel. Then you go into the off-shoot trail that takes you into the new DBD Monster Mash climb. \r\n\nNext, you'll come out and go into the main for a bit until you see a sign for Twisted Sister BD.  Exit that and you'll be in the Far East and come back on the main to the power lines and cross back over. You continue on the switchbacks of the main and you'll see a very sharp left that you can easily miss that is a bailout and will take you back to parking lot on Belle Meade Rd. \r\n\nIf you do that you have done the first half of the east side of ES which is about 7.5 miles. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039016/big-merlin-trail", "title": "Big Merlin Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.248816,-78.678082", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039016", "info-text": {"description": "Big Merlin is a smooth and rolling singletrack, easy to access from the parking area at its start, or from the short connector trail coming over from Holiday Valley.  \r\n\nAlthough the trail surfs the contour of the East McCarty Hill spur, it has plenty of climbing and descents. This trail starts at East McCarty Hill forest road near a popular parking spot. After a short bit it comes to the intersection with Porcupine Trail. Stay left and soon you'll enter a particularly nice section of red pine.\r\n\nThe trail starts to descend to meet up with an old log road that could take you to the bottom if you're interested. Instead, stay left and regain all that altitude you just lost.\r\n\nOnce back up top, you'll come across a bail out back to the road, but you'll stay right to stay on the trail.  This leads to a somewhat side hill section that brings you out to the end of a side spur.  Since it's the end, this means you get to descend again. This time you'll be on some nice bench cut and a switchback.\r\n\nAt the bottom, you'll follow an old log road briefly to start the climb back up. This quickly turns to singletrack along a nice bench cut sidehill climb. At the top, the trail heads left along an old log trail that brings you back from the end of this side spur. It turns to singletrack to stay on the side of the ridge. Soon the trail starts to descend again, only to climb back up. Are you starting to notice a pattern here?  \r\n\nJust in case all that climbing back up has tired your legs, the last part of this trail is relatively level, paralleling the last bit of East McCarty Hill Forest Rd. Where it crosses a small access trail, you can bail out to the road or continue on straight to Dead Dog Loop.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7038204/view-of-big-merlin-looking-uphill-from-the-switchback", "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 3.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2143, 1948], "alt-change": [385, 358], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 13.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039025/mesa-trail", "title": "Mesa Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.241328,-78.659693", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039025", "info-text": {"description": "The Mesa Trail is a loop off of Eagle Trail that provides some great views of Great Valley. Although it has some climbing, the relatively smooth surface and gradual grades make this a great trail for everyone.\r\n\nThe trail is fun in either direction. This description is for hiking the trail counter-clockwise.  It starts from a flat section of Eagle, well marked. The trail curves around a hilltop for a while until it starts a descent through some recent new growth. This is the biggest grade on the loop, and thus it's best to do it downhill.  Soon it crosses an old logging road and does a few up and downs until it joins another old logging road. This road is on a steep sidehill that affords some great views of the valley, especially when there are no leaves on the trees. The old logging road gives way to a section of sidehill singletrack.\r\n\nSoon it will be time to gain back that elevation you lost, but this is done in a gradual way with a series of long switchbacks each with a gradual climb. Eventually you reach the top which is a broad plateau (and hence the mesa name). Then the trail descends slightly on a nice bench cut to rejoin Eagle Trail.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2180, 2043], "alt-change": [155, 110], "avg-grade": 3.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039026/eagle-trail", "title": "Eagle Trail", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.250159,-78.656639", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039026", "info-text": {"description": "The trail so good they named a beer after it.  This is one of the best trails in Ellicottville and the best way to access the trail system.\r\n\nIt is a 100% singletrack two mile climb that gains 550 feet. The best thing is that if you park at the lot at the bottom, you do this all in the reverse on the way back, leaving you with a huge smile to end the day.\r\n\nThe very start actually is not singletrack, it's a doubletrack snowmobile trail. But that doesn't last long.  Soon after the creek crossing, you'll see the singletrack veer off to the left and the fun begins. The trail curves back around and after it crosses that very same creek again, it points uphill. Don't worry, this is the steepest part of the trail - it gets easier.  \r\n\nFor the next two miles, it is nothing but classic textbook bench cut as the trail climbs higher and higher up the ridge, switching back every so often.  ou get a short break about a third of the way up as it traverses a particularly scenic section of open woods, ending in a switchback at a dramatic steep creek. But climb on it does. It uses a very short section of an old log road about two-thirds up, but then the singletrack starts again swooping back and forth. The mesa trail leaves and rejoins the Eagle trail near the top, so make sure you add that to your hike in both directions. Eventually, the trail ends at sidewinder where you can continue on to the rest of the trails on East McCarty Hill.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 2.1, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2155, 1631], "alt-change": [551, 38], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 18.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039027/porcupine-trail", "title": "Porcupine Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.238495,-78.689625", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039027", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts at the end of Yukon's Lunch Trail. Another unmarked trail can be seen coming up from a clearing below. The trail curves its way around the nose of a spur and then enters a spruce grove on a nice sidehill cut.\r\n\nThe trail continues on the sidehill but soon after you see an old trail drop off to your left (which leads to a campsite off of Mutton Hollow Rd.) the roots start to get more pronounced, making the climb a little more challenging. Finally, you'll break into the deciduous trees again, just as the grade gets a little steeper. After a creek crossing, one last push leads you off, with even a little downhill to the crossing at Mutton Hollow Rd.\r\n\nAfter you cross the road, the climbing starts again after a brief level bit. You'll pass through a rocky section to get to a particularly scenic creek crossing. Cross the creek and start to double back uphill. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7039039/rim-trail", "title": "Rim Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.225697,-78.710664", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7039039", "info-text": {"description": "This is a favorite of many of the locals. It attracts many because of parking at the start, very little climbing (it is actually slightly downhill) and great views of the Salamanca Conglomerate falling off the plateau in large chunks.\r\n\nThe trail is called the Rim Trail because it is situated at the edge of the plateau formed by the erosion resistant conglomerate bedrock.  The shale underneath is not so solid, so as it erodes underneath it, large house size boulders break off and lean down the hill. While is most dramatic at Little Rock City down the road, this trail gives you a continuous view of the process while enjoying the hike.\r\n\nThe trail starts at the State Forest sign on Little Rock City Road. There is some limited parking there and a WNYMBA kiosk. The first 30 feet belie the flatness of the trail as it follows an old skid trail up the conglomerate bedrock to the plateau. This is very short. Once at the top, you go just a bit more to a campsite, and then make a sharp right onto the singletrack. This first section is rocky but (or \"therefore\") very fun. Soon you reach the rim itself. A short spur lets you hike out onto the top of one of the boulders if you are interested.\r\n\nOnce the trail hangs a left at the rim, it just swoops along for more than a mile, providing great views of the rocks on your right.  To the extent possible, the trail follows the edge of the rocks, so in some places be careful you don't fall off.\r\n\nThe trail ends at Eckert Forest Rd.  Across it is the start of Bent Rim trail.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 1.5, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2249, 2198], "alt-change": [57, 63], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036024/orange-trail", "title": "Orange Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=40.703562,-73.851461", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036024", "info-text": {"description": "In order to access the Orange Loop, you can start from either Park Lane South or Myrtle Avenue. There's no \"parking lot\", but plenty of room to park on the street and make your way onto it from the street. From Myrtle Avenue, cross the bridge on Myrtle Ave and make a sharp right into the woods. Follow the Blue Trail immediately ahead, and hike a few feet until you reach the intersection with the Orange Trail. \r\n\nMake a sharp left here and follow the Orange Trail for the rest of the hike. The first section has a small incline, followed by a drop into a nice pine wooded area. Coming out of here, you continue across the train tracks (make sure to look both ways before crossing). You then continue onto a slight downgrade, coming across a horse-crossing area. \r\n\nFollowing a small climb, you'll make your way along Jackie Robinson Parkway (along the trail) and up to Forest Park Drive. Instead of following the road, continue onto the Orange Trail, which takes you up into the trees. This is asphalt, but you can hike on the shoulder which is dirt. Make a sharp right and cross Forest Park Drive into a short climb. This is followed by a downhill crossing the main horse path. \r\n\nCross the bridge that goes over the train tacks, make a sharp right at the end of it onto the Orange Trail again. This section is nice and downhill, followed by a small up-climb. Coming across Forest Park Drive again, you'll head into Pine Grove\u2014make sure to enjoy the smell of this area. \r\n\nYou'll then have a small climb, followed by a big downhill (the biggest on the course). Cross Forest Park Drive again, following the Orange Trail until you come into a nice gradual climb. The top of this climb will give you a good view of parts of the park.
