(both dirt roads).  There you'll find the DEC state forest sign.  \r\n\nTo start the hike, head northeast on Fire Lane Rd. about a 100 yards or so and find the singletrack heading off to the right. Take that and find yourself on a scenic smooth widing trail, although in some places the trail squeezes between some closely spaced trees.  This pleasant rolling singletrack continues for a while until it joins an old grassy lane that heads pretty much straight uphill.\r\n\nClimb up this until you see an old abandoned two-wheeled trailer of some sort.  You could continue straight on a connector that bails out to the road, but you won't.  Instead, you take a right for a fun downhill that eventually levels off as it heads for the dirt Chapman Rd. (reaching the road through an informal campsite).\r\n\nCross the road making the slightest of jogs downhill and head back into the woods.  This part of the trail follows an old skid trail but again, mostly reverted to singletrack.  It climbs slightly until you reach the top, and then the trail heads left onto narrower singletrack.\r\n\nThis section is another fun rolling section with lots of variety.  Soon, you come to a spruce grove as you head left and climb up to Fire Lane Rd.\r\n\nWhen you reach the road, head right for a very short bit looking for the trail on your left.  Pick this up and start back on the singletrack.  This section has a spruce grove with some nasty roots, but they end soon enough.  \r\n\nAfter you see the blue loop start on your right, the red loop continues around the edge of another spruce grove eventually almost returing to Fire lane.  It then darts downhill and climbs back up on a section that can sometimes be wet.\r\n\nAfter the blue loop rejoins, you'll soon see a bailout connector to the road on your left.  Instead, continue straight for one of the best sections.  \r\n\nThe trail ends with a climb up through some scenic red pines before ending on Fire Lane Rd. opposite from where you started.", "features": "Fall Colors", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 3}, "stats": {"dist": 4.1, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [2247, 2066], "alt-change": [261, 282], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 7.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037673/golden-hill-blue-loop", "title": "Golden Hill Blue Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.258331,-78.525045", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037673", "info-text": {"description": "This is the more challenging of the two main loops at Golden Hill, but is still not hard, just more climbing at the end.  This loop is usually used to bypass the shorter section of the red loop up on top.\r\n\nThe loop starts on the Golden Hill Red loop not long after it exits the rooty spruce section (it can also be accessed from Fire Lane Rd. by cutting in the old logging road immediately opposite the Chapman Rd. intersection).\r\n\nThe trail immediately starts to lose elevation through some swoopy turns.  It eventually comes to an old skid trail that has fully reverted to singletrack -- just watch out for the berms installed by the loggers to trap water.\r\n\nThe trail keeps from losing too much elevation by skirting off to the left, briefly joining another old skid trail singletrack, before making a left again into a full sidehill section.  \r\n\nThis section was attacked by tent catepillars a few years back, opening up the canopy.  This improved the views, but also spurred heavy bushy growth; it's a challenge keeping this section from getting overgrown.  \r\n\nEventually, the trail gains the tip of a ridge, crosses the top, and then begins a fun winding downhill all the way to the bottom.  \r\n\nAt the bottom, there is a junction.  Going straight cuts off the finger-shaped portion of the lower route.  Actually, in some ways it is better to do the \"finger\" clockwise even though the rest of the blue loop is done ccounter-clockwise (and hence doing the connector  twice), but either way works.  \r\n\nThis description is for doing the connector counter-clockwise:  The trail slowly loses some elevation until it finally hits the dry creek bottom.  After crossing it here, it climbs up on a small ridge that had been paralleling the creek.  Making a U-turn at the top of the small ridge, it follows the ridge back to the connector.  \r\n\nGoing straight, you'll start to regain all that uphill you just descended.  It starts out gradual and rolling at first, but after a couple of creek crossings, it starts to get steep.  You'll see both ends of the whammy intersect, but that's for another description.  Instead, climb on climbing turn after climbing turn until you rejoin the red loop at the top.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2201, 1800], "alt-change": [402, 434], "avg-grade": 6.0, "max-grade": 16.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037674/the-whammy", "title": "The Whammy", "difficulty": "Very Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.251176,-78.537001", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037674", "info-text": {"description": "This is a side loop that adds some gratuitous technical riding in, just for the fun of it.\r\n\nIt starts and ends on the Golden Hill Blue Loop.  It's almost always done starting at the higher trailhead.  Look for the Whammy sign and start on some unassuming singletrack.  When you reach the creek, you have the option of crossing and doing just the lower whammy.  Instead, stay left and do a short climb before the trail curves right and descends.  This is not a steep descent, but there are some rocky sections.\r\n\nSoon you'll reach the above mentioned short cut.  This time, take it across the creek and descend this time on the left bank. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7037750/crescent-trail-orange", "title": "Crescent Trail (Orange)", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.105101,-77.407199", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7037750", "info-text": {"description": "Most sections of the Crescent Trail are single-lane dirt pathways. A continuous, orange-blazed main trail is nearly completed \u2013 planned as a crescent-shaped route between the southwest and northeast quadrants of Perinton. Additional branch trails, loop trails, connecting paths, and access paths allow self-guided walks of up to two hours. Longer, half-day or day-long outings can be enjoyed as point-to-point hikes or by using connections with the Trolley Trail or Canal Trail.\r\n\nThe Crescent Trail is a system of footpaths within the Town of Perinton suitable for uses such as hiking, cross-country running, snowshoeing, nature study, and photography. Approximately thirty-five miles of footpaths provide public access to wooded hills, Town parklands, scenic overlooks, the margins of wetlands, and other preserved open spaces. The trail also connects with the Erie Canal Heritage Trail and the RS&E Trolley Trail.", "features": "River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7047782/more-trail", "ratings": {"rating": 4.7, "num_reviewers": 6}, "stats": {"dist": 18.0, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [843, 459], "alt-change": [1120, 1147], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 24.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7038630/victory-woods-trail", "title": "Victory Woods Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.098417,-73.593438", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7038630", "info-text": {"description": "The Victory Woods Trail departs from the Prospect Hill Cemetery and makes its way through a wooded area where in October 1777, British troops surrendered to the US and swung the tide of the war in the American's favor. After parking your vehicle along Burgoyne Street, take a a few minutes to explore the Saratoga Monument. If you fancy a workout, climb the interior stairs to the top of the monument for sweeping views of the area.  \r\n\nOnce you get back down and collect your breath, look for a sign toward the cemetery that describes Victory Woods and what happened there. Follow the white dots on the ground through the cemetery, which was founded in the mid-1800s. The trail meanders through the cemetery along a private drive before heading downhill to the left. The trail moves onto a boardwalk near the end of Monument Drive, which provides an alternative parking location if you don't want to hike through the cemetery.  \r\n\nAs the trail moves through the woods, signs provide information about the experiences of the Colonial and British troops as they fought through this area. The boardwalk comes to a split where you can either go to the left or the right.  If you go to the left, the boardwalk leads to a dead end where there is a picnic table for you to relax. If you go to the right, more signs provide insight into the situation that people faced during the war. The trail is shaded throughout, so it can be enjoyed any time of the day.  \r\n\nFinally, arriving at a sign that marks the end of the trail at the edge of private property, your only real choice is to turn around and head back to your car. One day the trail may become part of the larger canal and rail to trail system that is found in the Hudson Valley, but for now enjoy the hike back through the woods.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7038310/the-picnic-area-at-the-end-of-the-boardwalk", "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [351, 307], "alt-change": [48, 44], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 6.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7038838/wilkinson-national-recreation-trail", "title": "Wilkinson National Recreation Trail", "difficulty": "Easy", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=43.011806,-73.648918", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7038838", "info-text": {"description": "The Wilkinson National Recreation Trail is a 4.2-mile trail that winds its way through Saratoga National Historical Park, providing visitors the opportunity to hike through the fields where the Revolutionary War was fought. The best place to park is the visitor center, where you can get a map and brochure that provides details about the landscape and the various information stations that you'll encounter. The trail departs the back of the visitor center and makes its way through the woods and fields of the park. The trail descends into the field below the visitor center where a horse trail crosses the trail.  \r\n\nAt a fork in the trail, take the right to cross the tour road and make your way through the British lines near John Freeman's Farm. At Station F, the Liason Trail breaks off to the left allowing you to cut the hike short and make your way back to your car. The trail continues straight ahead until it comes to a steep ravine that you need to climb. Crossing the tour road again, the trail begins to make its way back to the visitor center. After crossing the road again at about 3 miles, you encounter the Liason Trail shortcut you passed earlier.\r\n\nCrossing the road for the final time, the trail comes back to the fork that you encountered earlier. Follow the trail straight ahead back to the visitor center and your vehicle.\r\n\nThe Wilkinson Trail can be enjoyed at various points along the tour road, and sections of it can be used and enjoyed depending on the amount of time you have.   \r\n\nThe map and information station descriptions can be found here:   nps.gov/sara/planyourvisit/\u2026", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7038844/deer-run-across-the-trail-in-the-afternoon", "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 3.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [409, 244], "alt-change": [111, 239], "avg-grade": 2.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7038883/st-regis-mountain-trail", "title": "St. Regis Mountain Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.430496,-74.299064", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7038883", "info-text": {"description": "At 2,874 feet, St. Regis does not qualify as one of the ADK 46ers, but it is one of the Saranac Lake 6ers and part of the Fire Tower Challenge. This trail can be attempted year round, but winter hikers should use microspikes and snowshoes. \r\n\nFrom the road to Spectacle Ponds, the trail begins with gentle elevation in a hardwood forest with a lot of typical Adirondack glacial rock that seems to just pop up out of the ground. As you continue to hike following the yellow markers, the trail gradually gets steeper. Eventually, you begin climbing a stone staircase that will take you just about to the summit. \r\n\nAt 3.4 miles, you reach the mostly bald summit that has great views. There is a fire tower that has been restored and is open to the public. Though the stairs up the tower may seem scary to some, it is well worth overcoming the fear to enjoy the extended view from the tower.\r\n\nPlenty of parking is located on Keese Mills Road in Keese Mill, west of Paul Smith's College.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Minor Issues"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7039216/fire-tower-on-st-regis-yes-you-can-climb-it-and-you-should", "ratings": {"rating": 4.5, "num_reviewers": 4}, "stats": {"dist": 3.3, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2865, 1656], "alt-change": [1388, 182], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 39.0}},

Be sure to follow the white \"metal\" markers, not the painted ones. The trail itself is quite narrow on the east side of the park, but broadens on the north side and stays that way until you arrive at the pond heading east.  \r\n\nJust after the pond is a pine forest; it smells so good in the warmer months and there are lots of rabbits. The north side of the trail has two hawks living in the area. When the trail does widen, you should expect to see people with dogs, most are leashed. \r\n\nThere are quite a few trees down due to storms, but the Parks Department has cut paths through most of them or built steps to get over them. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7036220/vernooy-kill-falls-trail", "title": "Vernooy Kill Falls Trail", "difficulty": "Easy/Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.8641,-74.346432", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7036220", "info-text": {"description": "From Route 209 near Kerhonksen, turn onto Ulster County 3. After 1.3 miles, turn left onto Cherrytown Road. Drive about 3.5 miles and turn left onto Upper Cherrytown Road. Once on Upper Cherrytown, go 3.1 miles until you see the state trailhead sign on the right. Park and hike across the road to get on the trail. \r\n\nThe trail is marked with blue blazes, snowmobile markers, and the occasional aqua blazes of the Long Path. Hike 1.8 miles on this trail until you are at the bridge at the base of the falls. The falls are more of a set of rapids and cataracts than one continuous drop of water. \r\n\nHike upstream on either side to take in all the beauty of the various \"steps\" to the falls. There is no formal trail, but you'll have no trouble finding your way. Near the bridge are the ruins of a mill built by the Vernooy family who first owned the land. Standing on the rocks in the middle of the stream offers a great view of the bridge and many of the different steps to the falls. It also offers a good opportunity to fall in, so be careful. Runners will pass the historic Depot Building which was constructed in 1907. The trail is very flat and continues for one mile along the old rail bed. This section provides a peaceful experience of field and woodland beauty and wonderful mountain views. \r\n\nDescription courtesy of Catskill Mountain Club. This trail extends the Andes Rail Trail an additional 2 miles, bringing the combined mileage for the run to 4 miles round-trip. The spur climbs the ridge above the rail bed, taking runners through mature hardwood forest, open woodlands covered in ferns and princess pine, an old pine plantation and hemlocks towering above the Bullet Hole Creek. \r\n\nBullet Hole Spur Trail is a bit more strenuous than the Andes Rail Trail. There are a couple of well-designed, moderately steep sections, but they are followed by relatively flat sections so you get a nice breather after working a little harder. There are many wonderful views of the Tremperskill Valley from the spur. \r\n\nDescription based on that provided by the Catskill Mountain Club. There are several wooden ladders to climb along cliff sections before reacing the summit. \r\n\nThe summit offers beautiful 270 degree views to the south, west and north. The trail decends to a spring fed mountain side pond before splitting to offer two choices to descend. A steep and rocky decent to the wagon road and back to the Ski Hi Road trailhead, or a high crossing trail back to the orginal ascent trail and down.", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7068551/short-ladder-1st-depending-on-which-way-you-go", "ratings": {"rating": 4.6, "num_reviewers": 7}, "stats": {"dist": 3.2, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [3216, 1956], "alt-change": [1260, 1233], "avg-grade": 15.0, "max-grade": 49.0}},

Difficult areas are improved with steps constructed from rocks or wood. At the summit is a century old fire tower which you can climb. It is sometimes manned by a docent and has artifacts on display from when the tower was active. \r\n\nThe trail and structures are maintained by the Friends of Mt. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7056058/earl-cardot-eastside-overland-trail", "title": "Earl Cardot Eastside Overland Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.367439,-79.235891", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7056058", "info-text": {"description": "The Eastside Overland Trail starts in the Canadaway Creek Wildlife Management Area, continues through the Boutwell Hill State Forest, and ends in the Harris Hill State Forest. The trail connects to the forests through roads and in some cases on private property. This hike goes up to the closed section of trail. \r\n\nThe trail is mainly wide though in some sections is more like a singletrack trail. It goes through a variety of forest types. In multiple areas, it passes through spruce forests which will be logged in the future to regenerate native tree species to the area. There are multiple horse, snowmobile, and cross-country ski trails which go off of this trail.\r\n\nTrail maps and visitor sign-in registries are found at multiple spots along the trail. Parking is available at many locations in Canadaway Creek WMA on Bard Rd (2 lots) and Center Rd and in Boutwell Hill SF on Ruttenbur Rd and Boutwell Hill Rd.\r\n\nA map of the complete Eastside Overland Trail and the other trails within the State Forests can be found at the following websites:\r\nEastside Overland:  chautauqua.ny.us/737/Earl-C\u2026 \nCanadaway Creek WMA:  dec.ny.gov/outdoor/82659.html \nBoutwell Hill SF:  dec.ny.gov/lands/8270.html \nHarris Hill SF:  dec.ny.gov/lands/8269.html", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 4.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 11.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2151, 1446], "alt-change": [1439, 769], "avg-grade": 4.0, "max-grade": 21.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7009664/wa-white-trail", "title": "WA White Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.150719,-73.783674", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7009664", "info-text": {"description": "The ascent to Lower Wolfjaw via WA White Trail is moderately short, but not especially sweet. The trail winds through the scenic forest of the Adirondacks, which at this elevation should be turning into pine forests.\r\n\nWatch you footing, as the granite knob of Lower Wolfjaw begins to poke through on this portion of trail in the form of exposed boulders and rocks. Especially in wet weather, the trail tends to get muddy, so remember your LNT principles and try not to widen the existing path. \r\n\nLike all trails in this area, round blazes will mark your way, so keep an eye out for them!", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7038153/heading-down-from-the-summit", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 4.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [4128, 1370], "alt-change": [2766, 491], "avg-grade": 15.0, "max-grade": 34.0}},

{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003928/bull-wheel-trail", "title": "Bull Wheel Trail", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.740101,-74.219294", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003928", "info-text": {"description": "From a kiosk at the western end of the lower parking area, follow a wide path covered with wood chips that heads north, soon becoming a gravel road. At the top of a rise, a triple white blaze on a tree to the right marks the start of the Bull Wheel Trail. Turn right onto this trail, which climbs gradually on an old carriage road. After passing a trail sign on the left, the road becomes rocky and eroded, and it gradually narrows to a footpath.\r\n\nAt the crest of the rise, the trail passes a concrete slab, with steel bolts protruding. A tower that was anchored to the slab via the bolts once supported a pulley for a ski lift - part of the Ski Minne downhill ski area, which operated from 1964 to 1978. The pulley is commonly referred to as a \"bull wheel\" - hence the name for the trail.\r\n\nThis trail can be combined to form a loop by following the red blazes back to the parking area, or be hikeed simply as an out-and-back.", "features": "Fall Colors \u00b7 Views \u00b7 Wildflowers \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 2}, "stats": {"dist": 0.6, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [1266, 1131], "alt-change": [138, 4], "avg-grade": 5.0, "max-grade": 9.0}},
{"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7003930/peters-kill-red-loop", "title": "Peters Kill Red Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=41.738445,-74.219042", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7003930", "info-text": {"description": "This trail, marked by red blazes, starts from the parking area and follows the Peters Kill down to the High Peters Kill Trail.  The trailhead is on the left side of the parking area, just beyond the gatehouse.  It starts out as a carriage road and passes some cliffs on the right and some swampy areas on the left.  At the end of the carriage road, the red-marked trail turns right and follows a small stream.  It eventually crosses the stream and ascends some rocks.  The trail through the slab of rock is marked and should be followed.  Note that the rock can be slippery at times.  After descending from a high point, the trail follows a small stream.  About halfway, an unmarked trail appears on the right.  This is the Bull Wheel Trail.  It climbs the old ski slope back to the parking area.\r\n\nThe red-marked trail eventually meets the blue-marked High Peters Kill Trail.  Turn left to return to the Lower Awosting parking area.  Turn right to hike to the Coxing parking area in Mohonk Preserve.", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 2.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 0.9, "dist-type": "Loop", "alt-range": [1139, 907], "alt-change": [231, 231], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 17.0}},

After passing a small pond, the trail lets out on Fairbanks Road (dirt) before picking up again a little ways to the south at the edge of DeRuyter State Forest. Despite its geometric appearance on the map, the trail meanders naturally through mixed deciduous and evergreen forest and over several small streams. \r\n\nAn established and well-marked trailhead can be found at the northeast end of the trail, at the south end of Irish Hill Road, with a large pull-out for parking. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7086080/north-country-trail-nct-stone-quarry-hill", "title": "North Country Trail (NCT): Stone Quarry Hill", "difficulty": "Intermediate", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.921586,-75.849161", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7086080", "info-text": {"description": "This trail is part of the Link Trail portion of the NCT. The trail starts from a well-maintained parking lot on the east side of Chenango Street. The first mile is fairly flat, with long sections of boardwalks over the boggiest sections, running first east along the edge of the South Village neighborhood and then south through a strip of walnut and maple trees between two fields. \r\n\nFrom there, the trail climbs more steeply up the side of Stone Quarry Hill. At the top, one comes to a T junction with one of the Art Park trails; keep right, following the blue markings of the Link Trail and the starburst logo of the North Country Trail. Several art installations can be found along this section of trail, and near the end there are views of farms and hills to the southwest. The North County Trailway spans 22.1 miles in Westchester County, from Eastview in the Town of Mt. Pleasant, to Baldwin Place in Somers. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7102920/boquet-forks-trail-to-grace-peak", "title": "Boquet Forks Trail to Grace Peak", "difficulty": "Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=44.112401,-73.70809", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7102920", "info-text": {"description": "NOT FOR INEXPERIENCED HIKERS\r\n\nThis un-marked trail can be tricky to follow at times due to lack of blazing, infrequent travel, and multiple stream crossings. Downed trees and overgrowth are common, with the trail seemingly disappearing at times. Do not rely on this GPS track alone when traversing this path - a hard copy map of the local terrain, a keen awareness of your surroundings, and experience with unmarked trails is highly advised. Do not feel afraid to turn back if you lose the trail - better safe than lost!\r\n\nThe trailhead is unmarked on the side of Route 73, and is accessible from just south of the bridge over North Fork Boquet river where a short dirt road leads to a trail registry box (\"North Fork of Boquet\"). Gravel parking space available off the side of the northbound lane of 73, both north and south of the bridge. \r\n\nA small network of herd trails are present at the trailhead (which can be confusing to navigate), with access to both sides of the stream. During the latter half of the trail, multiple stream crossings are required, and the trail is often hard to find without paying close attention to rock cairns and maintaining a keen awareness of your surroundings. The last mile climbs steeply, and will require extra attention to stay on-path. \r\n\nThere are 3 primitive campsites posted with yellow 'tent' markers nailed to trees, at approx miles 1.5, 2.5, and 4. As with all eastern high peaks wilderness camping, no fires are allowed.\r\n\nSee this link for additional discussion:  adkhighpeaks.com/forums/for\u2026", "features": "Birding \u00b7 Fall Colors \u00b7 Lake \u00b7 River/Creek \u00b7 Wildlife", "condition": "Unknown"}, "photo": "https://www.hikingproject.com/photo/7080306/one-of-three-posted-camp-sites-on-the-boquet-forks-trail-to-grace-peak", "ratings": {"rating": 3.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 5.7, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [3796, 1340], "alt-change": [2642, 185], "avg-grade": 9.0, "max-grade": 51.0}},

Well-marked and easy to follow, the route begins with a gradual climb. Soon, the trail levels off until you come to the Lake Eaton trail junction at 1.2 miles.\r\n\nTurning left at the junction, continue to climb gradually until you are about one mile from the summit. At this point, the trail will become steeper and rocky as you make your way to the false summit. After passing over the false summit the trail drops slightly into a col where you'll see the remains of the old observer's cabin. From here you'll make your final steep push toward the summit.\r\n\nAt the top, the firetower is open to climb. On a clear day, you should easily be able to make out Blue Mountain in the distance.", "features": "Views", "condition": "Unknown"}, "ratings": {"rating": 5.0, "num_reviewers": 1}, "stats": {"dist": 2.2, "dist-type": "Point to Point", "alt-range": [2784, 1818], "alt-change": [1019, 88], "avg-grade": 10.0, "max-grade": 40.0}},

The trail starts from an unmarked parking area on the north side of Route 7. This trail follows red blazes, though some spots may still have some blue. It parallels the road for a short ways and crosses over a few small brooks.  \r\n\nThe trail turns left and climbs uphill, along an old logging trail. The trail turns right (off the logging trail) and follows a singletrack along the rocky edge of the hill. It turns right and, eventually, connects with another old logging trail. {"url": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/7108628/upper-forest-loop", "title": "Upper Forest Loop", "difficulty": "Intermediate/Difficult", "trailhead": "https://maps.google.com/?daddr=42.848386,-73.350479", "gpx": "https://www.hikingproject.com/trail/gpx/7108628", "info-text": {"description": "This trail starts from the parking area off the east side of Route 7. The trail enters the woods near a dilapidated kiosk and may follow yellow blazes.  Eventually, the markers turn to blue. The trail takes a left, then a right (at Lower Forest Loop). It climbs up the hills towards the edge of the property. There's a sign (at the top of the hill), directing you to turn right.  Here, the trail passes by a cellarhole and a small brook. The trail travels through a Chinquapin Oak Forest, then a mix of Hemlock, Pine and Ferns.
